title: Introduction to R
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Introduction to R
text:
Introduction to R
Welcome to the Introduction to R class!
Note that this site is an abridged version of the full 6 course class taught at a government agency. It has been modified for public display.
The repository is laid out as follows:

/exercises/: the R script (.R) and Quarto (.qmd) exercises that we will be working with throughout the course
/lesson_code/: the Quarto (.qmd) documents that are used to generate the html documents
/_site/: the html documents of the tutorials. Open up the index.html file to view the website and corresponding materials.


Prerequisites
No prior R experience is assumed to take this course. Before attending, please remember to ensure that R and R Studio have been downloaded.
Consider changing some options in RStudio before the class. Under the Tools -> Global Options menu items, you can customize multiple options to your preferences.
I recommend to:

In General
Uncheck Restore .Rdata into workspace at startup

Assign Never to Save workspace to .Rdata on exit

In Appearance

Play around with the Editor theme and decide on what you like

In R Markdown

Show output preview in View Pane
Uncheck Show output inline for RMarkdown documents




What is R?
R is a free, open source programming language for statistical computing and graphics. It is known for robust visualization capabilities and a growing library of statistical and analytic methods.
R has an exensive user base that benefit from the libraries that others have created through the Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN). CRAN is a network of FTP and web servers that store versions of code and documentation for R.
R is maintained by the R Foundation, a non-profit organization that supports the continued development of R for satistical and computational research.


What is RStudio?
RStudio is a free integrated development entironment (IDE) for R, created by the private organization Posit (formally RStudio). An IDE is a graphical user interface that consolidates different features helpful for writing code into one application. Other examples of IDEs include SAS Enterprise Guide, VSCode, Jupyter, or Spyder.
Which IDE you might choose might depend on the programming language and personal preference. However, I recommend using RStudio forR - it has the most built out features for programming in R.


Why R?

Open Source: R is made freely available and may be redistributed and modified by anyone.
Popular: R is one of the most popular statistical tools for data analysis. Given its growing popularity over paid softwares like SAS or Stata, future employees will likely know R or have some experience with it.
Excellent visualization tools: R excels at data manipulation, statistical analysis, machine learning, and reproduciability, but it is probably best known for its graphics. R visualizations are the gold standard for reproducible data visualizations.
Flexibility: Given its open source nature, R makes it easy to build off of work that others have already done. Over the past three decades, users have been contributing to the R ecosystem, which has allowed for the expansion of libraries and functions to do nearly any kind of data analysis task. If you have a data analysis need, it is likely that someone else has had a similar need and written code already to complete it.
Reproducible: Like most programming languages, R is fully reproducible and encourages workflows to be entirely reproducible. This means that you are able to run through the entire workflow, start to finish, and achieve the same results.



Other Resources

R for Data Science by Garret Grolemund and Hadley Wickham. This books is the gold standard for R programming. Co-written by the creator of tidyverse and ggplot2, this free book goes over the core concept of tidy data and how to work with tidy data in R.
ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis by Hadley Wickham. This book provides a more theoretical and comprehensive understanding of the decisions underlying the construction of ggplot2.
Text Mining with R: A Tidy Approach by Julia Silge and David Robinson. This book provides a comprehensive overview of text mining in R.
Geocomputation with R by Robin Lovelace, Jakub Nowosad, and James Muenchow. This book provides tutorials for how to do various spatial operations in R, including analyzing and modeling geographic data, mapping (both static and interactive), and statistical operations.
Hands-On Machine Learning with R by Bradley Boehmke and Brandon Greenwell. This book provides an overview of machine learning in R.
Cheat Sheets by Posit (formally RStudio). These cheat sheets are a great resource to provide an overview of relevant functions in many commonly-used packages.
HarvardX: Data Science: Visualization. This is an online course that goes over basic data visualization principles and how to apply them using ggplot2.

title: Exercise 5
text:
Exercise 5.1

ProblemSolution



Read in the data stored at lesson_code/02_lesson/data/class_data.csv and assign to class_data.
What is the current smallest level of observation for this data frame in relation to its rows? Remember, to view the data, type View(<data frame>) into the console. Hint: the level of observation should be unique by some combination of variables.
Reshape the data long such that grade represents a column with all grades and grade_type represents whether the grade is for a mid-term, a final exam, or overall. Assign to class_long.
What is the smallest unit of observation based on the rows now?
Reshape the data back to its original form.




Read in the data stored at lesson_code/02_lesson/data/class_data.csv and assign to class_data.



class_data <- read_csv("lesson_code/02_lesson/data/class_data.csv")



What is the current smallest level of observation for this data frame in relation to its rows? Remember, to view the data, type View(<data frame>) into the console. Hint: the level of observation should be unique by some combination of variables.

Class by Semester by Student


Reshape the data long such that grade represents a column with all grades and grade_type represents whether the grade is for a mid-term, a final exam, or overall. Assign to class_long.



class_long <- class_data |> 
  pivot_longer(cols = c(mid_term, 
                        final_exam, 
                        overall), 
               names_to = "grade_type", 
               values_to = "grade")

class_long

# A tibble: 48 × 6
   student class   attendance semester grade_type grade
     <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>    <dbl> <chr>      <chr>
 1       1 English         90        1 mid_term   A    
 2       1 English         90        1 final_exam A    
 3       1 English         90        1 overall    A    
 4       1 English         90        2 mid_term   A    
 5       1 English         90        2 final_exam A    
 6       1 English         90        2 overall    A    
 7       1 Science         90        1 mid_term   A    
 8       1 Science         90        1 final_exam A    
 9       1 Science         90        1 overall    A    
10       1 Science         90        2 mid_term   A    
# ℹ 38 more rows


 - What is the smallest unit of observation based on the rows now?
Grade by Grade Type by Semester by Class by Student

Reshape the data back to its original form.



class_long |> 
  pivot_wider(names_from = grade_type, 
              values_from = grade) |> 
  select(student,
         class,
         mid_term,
         final_exam,
         overall,
         attendance,
         semester) # reorder columns

# A tibble: 16 × 7
   student class          mid_term final_exam overall attendance semester
     <dbl> <chr>          <chr>    <chr>      <chr>        <dbl>    <dbl>

title: Exercise 5
text:
Exercise 5.2 - Challenge

ProblemSolution



Reshape the class_data data frame you created above such that you have 2 rows, one for each student.
Why is this data not tidy?




Reshape the class_data data frame you created above such that you have 2 rows, one for each student.


class_data |> 
  pivot_wider(names_from = c(class, 
                             semester), 
              values_from = c(mid_term, 
                              final_exam, 
                              overall, 
                              attendance))

# A tibble: 2 × 33
  student mid_term_English_1 mid_term_English_2 mid_term_Science_1
    <dbl> <chr>              <chr>              <chr>             
1       1 A                  A                  A                 
2       2 A                  A                  A                 
# ℹ 29 more variables: mid_term_Science_2 <chr>,
#   `mid_term_Social Studies_1` <chr>, `mid_term_Social Studies_2` <chr>,
#   mid_term_PE_1 <chr>, mid_term_PE_2 <chr>, final_exam_English_1 <chr>,
#   final_exam_English_2 <chr>, final_exam_Science_1 <chr>,
#   final_exam_Science_2 <chr>, `final_exam_Social Studies_1` <chr>,
#   `final_exam_Social Studies_2` <chr>, final_exam_PE_1 <chr>,
#   final_exam_PE_2 <chr>, overall_English_1 <chr>, overall_English_2 <chr>, …




Why is this data not tidy?


The column names are a combination of multiple underlying variables.






Note



If we want to amke a student level dataset where every observation is a column, we may want to instead keep our data to student-level values as opposed to grade-level. In R, it is much better to try to represent the smallest unit of observation long as opposed to wide, as R is designed to be optimized over vectors. In fact, we generlly want to separate out data frames at different levels of observation (such as semester) to different data frames, unless we have a specific use case for using them.

title: Working With Strings
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Working With Strings
text:
Concatenate Strings
The str_c() function, like the paste() function, concatenates strings. It is better than paste() because it handles missing values better (like most tidyverse functions).


starwars |> 
  mutate(hair_eye_info = str_c(hair_color, 
                               " hair and ", 
                               eye_color, 
                               " eyes")) |> # concatenate strings
  count(hair_eye_info) # tabulate frequencies

# A tibble: 31 × 2
   hair_eye_info                             n
   <chr>                                 <int>
 1 auburn hair and blue eyes                 1
 2 auburn, grey hair and blue eyes           1
 3 auburn, white hair and blue-gray eyes     1
 4 black hair and blue eyes                  2
 5 black hair and brown eyes                 9
 6 black hair and dark eyes                  1
 7 black hair and yellow eyes                1
 8 blond hair and blue eyes                  3
 9 blonde hair and yellow eyes               1
10 brown hair and blue eyes                  7
# ℹ 21 more rows

title: Working With Strings
text:
String Length
Like nchar(), the str_length() function provides the length of each element of a string (number of characters).


starwars |> 
  head() |> # get just first 6 rows
  pull(name) |> # this function accesses one vector from a data frame
  str_length() # get length of strings

[1] 14  5  5 11 11  9

title: Working With Strings
text:
String Matching
One of my most used stringr functions is a str_detect(), which returns TRUE if a pattern is matched in a string and FALSE otherwise for each element.


starwars |> 
  filter(str_detect(name, "Skywalker")) # keep only those that have "Skywalker" in the name variable

# A tibble: 3 × 14
  name      height  mass hair_color skin_color eye_color birth_year sex   gender
  <chr>      <int> <dbl> <chr>      <chr>      <chr>          <dbl> <chr> <chr> 
1 Luke Sky…    172    77 blond      fair       blue            19   male  mascu…
2 Anakin S…    188    84 blond      fair       blue            41.9 male  mascu…
3 Shmi Sky…    163    NA black      fair       brown           72   fema… femin…
# ℹ 5 more variables: homeworld <chr>, species <chr>, films <list>,
#   vehicles <list>, starships <list>



This course is too short for us to go deep into regular expressions, but you can also include regular expressions for better searching. They are a concise language for describing patterns in strings.
See this R Cheat Sheet for more.

title: Working With Strings
text:
Leading Zeros
One of the most useful functions when dealing with numeric identifiers is the str_pad9) function, which allows you to pad strings with specific constants to a specified width.
The str_pad() function has these relevant arguments:

string: input vector (can be numeric)
width: minimum width of padded strings
side: side on which padding character is added (“left”, “right”, “both”)
pad: Single padding character



# assign california geoids
tract_geoids <- c(6001400100, 
                  6001400200, 
                  6001400300, 
                  6001400400, 
                  6001400500)

# add leading zeros on the left side
str_pad(string = tract_geoids, 
        width = 11, 
        side = "left", 
        pad = "0")

[1] "06001400100" "06001400200" "06001400300" "06001400400" "06001400500"

title: Working With Strings
text:
White Space
The str_trim() function allws you to trim white space from the start and/or end of a string.


white_space <- c("   Is", 
                 "there", 
                 " whitespace?  ") # create character vector with white space included

str_trim(white_space) # trim white space

[1] "Is"          "there"       "whitespace?"

title: Working With Strings
text:
Subset string by index
Sometimes we’d like to subset strings based on their index position.
We can use str_sub() for that. If you pt in the same digit, the result in one character at that index.


# pull first character in string
starwars |> 
  pull(gender) |> # get only the gender column as a vector
  str_sub(1,1) # get first character

 [1] "m" "m" "m" "m" "f" "m" "f" "m" "m" "m" "m" "m" "m" "m" "m" "m" "m" NA  "m"
[20] "m" "m" "m" "m" "m" "m" "m" "f" "m" "m" "m" "m" "m" "m" "f" "m" "m" "m" "m"
[39] "m" "m" "m" "f" "m" "m" "f" "m" "m" "m" "m" "m" "m" "m" "m" "f" "m" "m" "m"
[58] "m" NA  NA  "m" "m" "f" "f" "f" "m" "m" "m" "f" "m" "m" "f" "f" "f" "m" "m"
[77] "f" "m" "m" "m" NA  "m" "m" "f" "m" "m" "f"


 In R, everything starts at 1, not 0, like in some other programming languages.

title: Working With Strings
text:
Modify Cases
There are a bunch of functions to modify case:

str_to_lower(): Convert strings to lower case (asdfjl)
str_to_upper(): Convert strings to upper case (ASDFJL)
str_to_title(): Convert strings to title case (This Is A Title)
str_to_sentence(): Convert strings to sentence case (This is a sentence)

title: Vectorized Conditions
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Vectorized Conditions
section: Modify or create up to two values with if_else()
text:
Modify or create up to two values with if_else()
The if_else() function takes in a logical vector, an element to return if the condistion is TRUE, and an element to return if the conditions is FALSE. If the condition evaluates to NA (missing), the result of the function will be NA for that value.
We often use if_else() in a mutate() function when we want to add or modify variables.


starwars |> 
  mutate(is_tall = if_else(height > 120, "Tall", "Not Tall")) |> # if expression is met, assign "Tall", otherwise "Not Tall"
  count(is_tall) # tabulate category variable we just created

# A tibble: 3 × 2
  is_tall      n
  <chr>    <int>
1 Not Tall     8
2 Tall        73
3 <NA>         6



Remember that the count variable tabulates frequency for each unique value in a variable.
We can also use this function to modify a value in an existing variable.


starwars |> 
  mutate(height = if_else(is.na(height), -999, height)) # if height is missing, set it as -999, else put height. Also, never do this. 


The above code changes all missing values in the height variable to -999. Note that we use the height variable in the false argument in order to assign values back to height if it is not missing. So this would be read as “if height is missing, -999, else height”.

title: Vectorized Conditions
section: Modify or create any number of values with case_when()
text:
Modify or create any number of values with case_when()
Sometimes we’d like to make more than one modification or create a variable that has multiple changes relative to its inputs.
If we wanted to do this with if_else(), we may need multiple nested if_else() statements.


starwars |> 
  mutate(is_tall = if_else(height < 80, 
                           "Short", # if height is greater than 80, assign "Short
                           if_else(height >= 80 & height <= 200, # else if this condition is met, assign Medium
                                   "Medium", 
                                   if_else(height > 200, # else if this condition is met, assign Tall
                                   "Tall", 
                                   as.character(height))))) |> # else assign back to height
  count(is_tall) # tabulate frequencies

# A tibble: 4 × 2
  is_tall     n
  <chr>   <int>
1 Medium     69
2 Short       2
3 Tall       10
4 <NA>        6



This can be cumbersome and hard to track. Instead, we can use the case_when() function.


starwars |> 
  mutate(height_category = case_when(
    height < 80 ~ "Short", # if height is greater than 80, assign "Short"
    height >= 80 & height <= 200 ~ "Medium", # else if this condition is met, assign Medium
    height > 200 ~ "Tall" # else if this condition is met, assign Tall
  )) |> 
  count(height_category) # tabulate frequencies

# A tibble: 4 × 2
  height_category     n
  <chr>           <int>
1 Medium             69
2 Short               2
3 Tall               10
4 <NA>                6



The arguments in case_when() are evaluated in order, so you must proceed from the most specific to the most general. For example, this won’t work:


x <- 1:70 
case_when(
  x %% 5 == 0 ~ "fizz", 
  x %% 7 == 0 ~ "buzz", 
  x %% 35 == 0 ~ "fizz buzz", 
  .default = as.character(x)
)

 [1] "1"    "2"    "3"    "4"    "fizz" "6"    "buzz" "8"    "9"    "fizz"
[11] "11"   "12"   "13"   "buzz" "fizz" "16"   "17"   "18"   "19"   "fizz"
[21] "buzz" "22"   "23"   "24"   "fizz" "26"   "27"   "buzz" "29"   "fizz"
[31] "31"   "32"   "33"   "34"   "fizz" "36"   "37"   "38"   "39"   "fizz"
[41] "41"   "buzz" "43"   "44"   "fizz" "46"   "47"   "48"   "buzz" "fizz"
[51] "51"   "52"   "53"   "54"   "fizz" "buzz" "57"   "58"   "59"   "fizz"
[61] "61"   "62"   "buzz" "64"   "fizz" "66"   "67"   "68"   "69"   "fizz"

title: Combining Data Frames
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Combining Data Frames
text:
Appending Data
To append data together, we can use the bind_rows() function.
This function takes in two or more data frames and appends them together, matching the columns with the same name together.
Let’s try it in code. 

# echo: false

df1 <- tibble(a = c(1, 
                    2, 
                    3), 
              b = c(4, 
                    5, 
                    6), 
              df = "first")

df2 <- tibble(a = c(4, 
                    5, 
                    6), 
              c = c(4, 
                    5, 
                    6), 
              df = "second")


df1

# A tibble: 3 × 3
      a     b df   
  <dbl> <dbl> <chr>
1     1     4 first
2     2     5 first
3     3     6 first

df2

# A tibble: 3 × 3
      a     c df    
  <dbl> <dbl> <chr> 
1     4     4 second
2     5     5 second
3     6     6 second

# append data together vertically
bind_rows(df1, df2)

# A tibble: 6 × 4
      a     b df         c
  <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <dbl>
1     1     4 first     NA
2     2     5 first     NA
3     3     6 first     NA
4     4    NA second     4
5     5    NA second     5
6     6    NA second     6



Note that the two dataframes shared the common columns a and df, while they did not share b and c. The appending still worked, and NAs were created where there was no data.

title: Combining Data Frames
text:
Joining With No Keys
One way to join tables together is joining without a key. By key, I mean a unique variable or set of variables that are shared across the dataframes you want to join. I do not recommend doing this often as the rows on each side of the join will be binded in the order that they appear in the data, so it is easy to create a mistake or meaningless results.
We can do this with the bind_cols() function.

 Let’s take a look at these data frames and bind them. 

df3

# A tibble: 3 × 2
      a     b
  <dbl> <dbl>
1     1     4
2     2     5
3     3     6

df4

# A tibble: 3 × 2
      c     d
  <dbl> <dbl>
1     1     4
2     2     5
3     3     6

# append data together horizontally 
bind_cols(df3, df4)

# A tibble: 3 × 4
      a     b     c     d
  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
1     1     4     1     4
2     2     5     2     5
3     3     6     3     6

title: Combining Data Frames
text:
Joining Data With Keys
It is a much more common use case where we want to join data with keys. That is, we want elements of one dataset to be matched to the same elements across another dataset.
For this, we can use joins.
Here are four functions for doing joins in the tidyr package (loaded in tidyverse).

 
Each kind of join tries to join two datasets together by row. The venn diagram above refers to what will happen to observations where keys are shared between the two data frames, what will happen when only x has a specific kehy, and what will happen when only y has a specific key.
Let’s start with an inner_join().
Let’s say we have the following data frames.


df1

# A tibble: 3 × 2
  geoid county_name   
  <chr> <chr>         
1 01001 Autauga County
2 01003 Baldwin County
3 01005 Barbour County

df2

# A tibble: 3 × 2
  fips  population
  <chr>      <dbl>
1 01005    1609492
2 01003      29629
3 01057     203921



Note that there seems to be a key that is shared across the two data frames, although the names do not match. We can still do the join based on that key with the following syntax.


# join data such that only rows with values in key from both sides of join are retained
inner_join(df1, df2, join_by(geoid == fips))

# A tibble: 2 × 3
  geoid county_name    population
  <chr> <chr>               <dbl>
1 01003 Baldwin County      29629
2 01005 Barbour County    1609492



We see here that the result is only two rows, because only two rows had shared keys across both datasets (01003 and 01005).
Here’s what the othr join result in.


# join data such that only rows with values in key from left side of join are retained
left_join(df1, df2, join_by(geoid == fips))

# A tibble: 3 × 3
  geoid county_name    population
  <chr> <chr>               <dbl>
1 01001 Autauga County         NA
2 01003 Baldwin County      29629
3 01005 Barbour County    1609492



# join data such that only rows with values in key from right side of join are retained
right_join(df1, df2, join_by(geoid == fips))

# A tibble: 3 × 3
  geoid county_name    population
  <chr> <chr>               <dbl>
1 01003 Baldwin County      29629
2 01005 Barbour County    1609492
3 01057 <NA>               203921



# join data such that all rows are maintained from bothdata frames, regardless of key matches
full_join(df1, df2, join_by(geoid == fips))

# A tibble: 4 × 3
  geoid county_name    population
  <chr> <chr>               <dbl>
1 01001 Autauga County         NA
2 01003 Baldwin County      29629
3 01005 Barbour County    1609492
4 01057 <NA>               203921



If you know SQL, here are the analogs to SQL joins, as tidyr’s join syntax was inspired by SQL.



We also can join across multiple variables using similar syntax. 

df1

# A tibble: 3 × 3
  state county county_name   
  <chr> <chr>  <chr>         
1 01    001    Autauga County
2 01    003    Baldiwn County
3 01    005    Barbour County

df2

# A tibble: 3 × 3
  state_code fips  population
  <chr>      <chr>      <dbl>
1 01         005      1609492
2 01         003        29629
3 01         057       203921

# do inner join with two columns
inner_join(df1, df2, join_by(state == state_code, 
                             county == fips))

# A tibble: 2 × 4
  state county county_name    population
  <chr> <chr>  <chr>               <dbl>
1 01    003    Baldiwn County      29629
2 01    005    Barbour County    1609492




Using the tidylog package
I have not yet mentioned this package, and yet it is one of my favorite packages in R. The tidylog package prints to the console some helpful information whenever we do certain tidyverse functions. It is especially helpful with joins because we can see how many observations were joined and not joined on each side.
We load tidylog after we load tidyverse to use it correctly.


library(tidylog)


# do inner join with two columns
inner_join(df1, df2, join_by(state == state_code, 
                             county == fips))

inner_join: added one column (population)
            > rows only in df1 (1)
            > rows only in df2 (1)
            > matched rows      2
            >                  ===
            > rows total        2


# A tibble: 2 × 4
  state county county_name    population
  <chr> <chr>  <chr>               <dbl>
1 01    003    Baldiwn County      29629
2 01    005    Barbour County    1609492









Note



The join_by() function is relatively new so the latest version of tidylog on CRAN may not have updated yet to incorporate it. To use the join_by() function with tidylog, first install the remotes package, then type remotes::install_github("elbersb/tidylog") into the console.

title: R Basics
text:
Comments
Comments in R are created with the # character. We use comments to give the reader of code (which is sometimes yourself in 6 months) an indication of what you are doing and why. Use them frequently to explain what you are doing to those reading your code.
For multi-line comments, highlight the lines you would like to comment and Shift + CTRL + C.


# This is a comment

# This comment
# is multi-line

title: R Basics
text:
Assignment
We’ve already discussed that we can use R like a calculator.


# use R like a calculator
3 + 4

[1] 7



The <- operator allows you to assign whateer is on the right hand side to an object name on the left hand side in the format of <obj_name> <- <expr>. This does two things:


Creates an object. You can think of an object like you would in real life, but in the virtual world (basically any kind of noun).
Creates a name that points to that object.


This allows you to reference the object that the object name points to without needing to type in the values again.


#assign values to an object reference
var <- 3 + 4

var

[1] 7



The <- operator is used as opposed to most programming languages where the default assignment is =. In R, = does work for assignment, but it is best practice to use <-.







Note



If you type th eobject name without assignment, it wil print the result automatically.




Valid Names
Object name must consist of letters, digits, and _. They cannot begin with a _ or a digit.
R will not let hyou use names that are reserved, like if or function. It is also bad practice to overwrite base functions or other functions that you would like to use (like mean()).

title: dplyr Basics
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: dplyr Basics
text:
The starwars data frame
Let’s take a look at some fiunctions within dplyr in more detail.
We’ll be using the dplyr::starwars tibble, a dataset about the characters in the starwars universe.
You can view it in our environment window if you assign it to itself.


# assign starwars to itself to view it in the environment window

starwars <- starwars

title: dplyr Basics
section: Take a look at the data with glimpse()
text:
Take a look at the data with glimpse()
To get some metadata about the data frame, we can use the glimpse() function.


glimpse(starwars)

Columns: 14

$ hair_color <chr> "blond", NA, NA, "none", "brown", "brown, grey", "brown", N…
$ skin_color <chr> "fair", "gold", "white, blue", "white", "light", "light", "…
$ eye_color  <chr> "blue", "yellow", "red", "yellow", "brown", "blue", "blue",…
$ birth_year <dbl> 19.0, 112.0, 33.0, 41.9, 19.0, 52.0, 47.0, NA, 24.0, 57.0, …
$ sex        <chr> "male", "none", "none", "male", "female", "male", "female",…
$ gender     <chr> "masculine", "masculine", "masculine", "masculine", "femini…
$ homeworld  <chr> "Tatooine", "Tatooine", "Naboo", "Tatooine", "Alderaan", "T…
$ species    <chr> "Human", "Droid", "Droid", "Human", "Human", "Human", "Huma…

$ starships  <list> <"X-wing", "Imperial shuttle">, <>, <>, "TIE Advanced x1",…



This function tells us the number of rows and columns of the data frame, the variable names, their type, and the first few observations.

title: dplyr Basics
text:
Add new variables with mutate()
mutate() creates new variables or edits existing variables.
The syntax for mutate() is:

mutate(.data = <df_name>, 
       <new_var_1> = <expr_1>, 
       <new_var_2> = <expr_2>
      )


For example, let’s say we want to create a new height variable that is half of the original height (editing an existing variable), and we wanted to add a varaible called type with a constant “movie_character”.


starwars_1 <- mutate(.data = starwars, 
                     height = height / 2, # edit existing varaible
                     type = "movie character"
                     )

glimpse(starwars_1)

Rows: 87
Columns: 15
$ name       <chr> "Luke Skywalker", "C-3PO", "R2-D2", "Darth Vader", "Leia Or…
$ height     <dbl> 86.0, 83.5, 48.0, 101.0, 75.0, 89.0, 82.5, 48.5, 91.5, 91.0…
$ mass       <dbl> 77.0, 75.0, 32.0, 136.0, 49.0, 120.0, 75.0, 32.0, 84.0, 77.…
$ hair_color <chr> "blond", NA, NA, "none", "brown", "brown, grey", "brown", N…
$ skin_color <chr> "fair", "gold", "white, blue", "white", "light", "light", "…
$ eye_color  <chr> "blue", "yellow", "red", "yellow", "brown", "blue", "blue",…
$ birth_year <dbl> 19.0, 112.0, 33.0, 41.9, 19.0, 52.0, 47.0, NA, 24.0, 57.0, …
$ sex        <chr> "male", "none", "none", "male", "female", "male", "female",…
$ gender     <chr> "masculine", "masculine", "masculine", "masculine", "femini…
$ homeworld  <chr> "Tatooine", "Tatooine", "Naboo", "Tatooine", "Alderaan", "T…
$ species    <chr> "Human", "Droid", "Droid", "Human", "Human", "Human", "Huma…
$ films      <list> <"A New Hope", "The Empire Strikes Back", "Return of the J…
$ vehicles   <list> <"Snowspeeder", "Imperial Speeder Bike">, <>, <>, <>, "Imp…
$ starships  <list> <"X-wing", "Imperial shuttle">, <>, <>, "TIE Advanced x1",…
$ type       <chr> "movie character", "movie character", "movie character", "m…



We’ll get to more complicated variable generations next class.

title: dplyr Basics
text:
Remove observations with filter()
One very common task is removing observations from a dataset. If we want to limit observations based off of information in the dataset, we can use the filter() function.
We use a logical vector that we can either create in the filter() function call or access already in the dataset (if it exists as a variable already).
For example, let’s keep only observations where the height is less than 100 cm.


# create logical vector in filter() function call 

filter(.data = starwars, 
       height < 100)

# A tibble: 7 × 14
  name      height  mass hair_color skin_color eye_color birth_year sex   gender
  <chr>      <int> <dbl> <chr>      <chr>      <chr>          <dbl> <chr> <chr> 
1 R2-D2         96    32 <NA>       white, bl… red               33 none  mascu…
2 R5-D4         97    32 <NA>       white, red red               NA none  mascu…
3 Yoda          66    17 white      green      brown            896 male  mascu…
4 Wicket S…     88    20 brown      brown      brown              8 male  mascu…
5 Ratts Ty…     79    15 none       grey, blue unknown           NA male  mascu…
6 Dud Bolt      94    45 none       blue, grey yellow            NA male  mascu…
7 R4-P17        96    NA none       silver, r… red, blue         NA none  femin…
# ℹ 5 more variables: homeworld <chr>, species <chr>, films <list>,
#   vehicles <list>, starships <list>



There is no logical vector in the starwars data frame yet, but we’ll create one soon.
You can use logical operators, | (or) and “&” (and), as well.


# filter observations with height < 100 OR species equal to "Droid" 

filter(.data = starwars, 
       height < 100 | species == "Droid")

# A tibble: 10 × 14
   name     height  mass hair_color skin_color eye_color birth_year sex   gender
   <chr>     <int> <dbl> <chr>      <chr>      <chr>          <dbl> <chr> <chr> 
 1 C-3PO       167    75 <NA>       gold       yellow           112 none  mascu…
 2 R2-D2        96    32 <NA>       white, bl… red               33 none  mascu…
 3 R5-D4        97    32 <NA>       white, red red               NA none  mascu…
 4 Yoda         66    17 white      green      brown            896 male  mascu…
 5 IG-88       200   140 none       metal      red               15 none  mascu…
 6 Wicket …     88    20 brown      brown      brown              8 male  mascu…
 7 Ratts T…     79    15 none       grey, blue unknown           NA male  mascu…
 8 Dud Bolt     94    45 none       blue, grey yellow            NA male  mascu…
 9 R4-P17       96    NA none       silver, r… red, blue         NA none  femin…
10 BB8          NA    NA none       none       black             NA none  mascu…
# ℹ 5 more variables: homeworld <chr>, species <chr>, films <list>,
#   vehicles <list>, starships <list>




# filter observations with height < 100 AND species equal to "Droid" 

filter(.data = starwars, 
       height < 100 & species == "Droid")

# A tibble: 3 × 14
  name   height  mass hair_color skin_color  eye_color birth_year sex   gender  
  <chr>   <int> <dbl> <chr>      <chr>       <chr>          <dbl> <chr> <chr>   
1 R2-D2      96    32 <NA>       white, blue red               33 none  masculi…
2 R5-D4      97    32 <NA>       white, red  red               NA none  masculi…
3 R4-P17     96    NA none       silver, red red, blue         NA none  feminine
# ℹ 5 more variables: homeworld <chr>, species <chr>, films <list>,
#   vehicles <list>, starships <list>



You can do the same thing, which is include multiple conditions that all must be TRUE for observations to be retained, by separating conditions with a comma.


# filter observations with height < 100 AND species equal to "Droid"

filter(.data = starwars,
       height < 100, 
       species == "Droid")

# A tibble: 3 × 14
  name   height  mass hair_color skin_color  eye_color birth_year sex   gender  
  <chr>   <int> <dbl> <chr>      <chr>       <chr>          <dbl> <chr> <chr>   
1 R2-D2      96    32 <NA>       white, blue red               33 none  masculi…
2 R5-D4      97    32 <NA>       white, red  red               NA none  masculi…
3 R4-P17     96    NA none       silver, red red, blue         NA none  feminine
# ℹ 5 more variables: homeworld <chr>, species <chr>, films <list>,
#   vehicles <list>, starships <list>

title: dplyr Basics
section: Remove, rename, and reorder columns with select()
text:
Remove, rename, and reorder columns with select()
select() drops columns from a data frame and/or reorders the columns in a data frame. The arguments after the name of the data frame should be the names of columns you wish to keep, without quotes. All other columns not listed are dropped.
To rename a variable, use the syntax <new_name>  = <old_name>.


# remove, rename, and/or reorder variables

select(.data = starwars, 
       name, 
       height,
       eye_color,
       year = birth_year)

# A tibble: 87 × 4
   name               height eye_color  year
   <chr>               <int> <chr>     <dbl>
 1 Luke Skywalker        172 blue       19  
 2 C-3PO                 167 yellow    112  
 3 R2-D2                  96 red        33  
 4 Darth Vader           202 yellow     41.9
 5 Leia Organa           150 brown      19  
 6 Owen Lars             178 blue       52  
 7 Beru Whitesun Lars    165 blue       47  
 8 R5-D4                  97 red        NA  
 9 Biggs Darklighter     183 brown      24  
10 Obi-Wan Kenobi        182 blue-gray  57  
# ℹ 77 more rows



The tidyselect::everything() function lets us refer to all other varaibles not explitly already defined in the select() function. This helps when we want to reorder some variables and leave the rest alone.


starwars_1 <- select(.data = starwars, 
                     name, 
                     height,
                     eye_color,
                     year = birth_year,
                     everything())

glimpse(starwars_1)

Columns: 14
$ name       <chr> "Luke Skywalker", "C-3PO", "R2-D2", "Darth Vader", "Leia Or…
$ height     <int> 172, 167, 96, 202, 150, 178, 165, 97, 183, 182, 188, 180, 2…
$ eye_color  <chr> "blue", "yellow", "red", "yellow", "brown", "blue", "blue",…
$ year       <dbl> 19.0, 112.0, 33.0, 41.9, 19.0, 52.0, 47.0, NA, 24.0, 57.0, …

$ skin_color <chr> "fair", "gold", "white, blue", "white", "light", "light", "…
$ sex        <chr> "male", "none", "none", "male", "female", "male", "female",…
$ gender     <chr> "masculine", "masculine", "masculine", "masculine", "femini…
$ homeworld  <chr> "Tatooine", "Tatooine", "Naboo", "Tatooine", "Alderaan", "T…

title: dplyr Basics
text:
Sort rows with arrange()
arrange() sorts rows of a data frame, similar to how sort() sorts an individual vector. The data frame is sortd by the first variable first and then each subsequent variable. desc(<var_name>) is used to reverse the sort of a given variable.

starwars_1 <- arrange(.data = starwars, desc(height))

glimpse(starwars_1)

Rows: 87
Columns: 14
$ name       <chr> "Yarael Poof", "Tarfful", "Lama Su", "Chewbacca", "Roos Tar…
$ height     <int> 264, 234, 229, 228, 224, 216, 213, 206, 206, 202, 200, 198,…
$ mass       <dbl> NA, 136, 88, 112, 82, 159, NA, NA, 80, 136, 140, 82, 102, 6…
$ hair_color <chr> "none", "brown", "none", "brown", "none", "none", "none", "…
$ skin_color <chr> "white", "brown", "grey", "unknown", "grey", "brown, white"…
$ eye_color  <chr> "yellow", "blue", "black", "blue", "orange", "green, yellow…
$ birth_year <dbl> NA, NA, NA, 200.0, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, 41.9, 15.0, 92.0, NA…
$ sex        <chr> "male", "male", "male", "male", "male", "male", "female", "…
$ gender     <chr> "masculine", "masculine", "masculine", "masculine", "mascul…
$ homeworld  <chr> "Quermia", "Kashyyyk", "Kamino", "Kashyyyk", "Naboo", "Kale…
$ species    <chr> "Quermian", "Wookiee", "Kaminoan", "Wookiee", "Gungan", "Ka…
$ films      <list> "The Phantom Menace", "Revenge of the Sith", "Attack of th…

title: dplyr Basics
text:
Tabulate frequencies with count()
The count() function tabulates frequencies by category. If you include multiple varaibles, it creates a long data frame with each unique combination of variables.


# tabulate by one variable

count(starwars, gender)

# A tibble: 3 × 2
  gender        n
  <chr>     <int>
1 feminine     17
2 masculine    66
3 <NA>          4




# tabulate by more than one variable

count(starwars, 
      gender,
      species)

# A tibble: 42 × 3
   gender    species        n
   <chr>     <chr>      <int>
 1 feminine  Clawdite       1
 2 feminine  Droid          1
 3 feminine  Human          9
 4 feminine  Kaminoan       1
 5 feminine  Mirialan       2
 6 feminine  Tholothian     1
 7 feminine  Togruta        1
 8 feminine  Twi'lek        1
 9 masculine Aleena         1
10 masculine Besalisk       1
# ℹ 32 more rows

title: dplyr Basics
text:
Group data with group_by()
group_by() groups data frame so subsequent functions will be evaluated by group instead of on all observations as a whole. We can combine group_by() with most dplyr functions that affect rows. Note that grouping by itself will not materially change the rows and columns of the data frame.


grouped <- group_by(.data = starwars, 
                    species)

glimpse(grouped)

Rows: 87
Columns: 14
Groups: species [38]
$ name       <chr> "Luke Skywalker", "C-3PO", "R2-D2", "Darth Vader", "Leia Or…
$ height     <int> 172, 167, 96, 202, 150, 178, 165, 97, 183, 182, 188, 180, 2…
$ mass       <dbl> 77.0, 75.0, 32.0, 136.0, 49.0, 120.0, 75.0, 32.0, 84.0, 77.…
$ hair_color <chr> "blond", NA, NA, "none", "brown", "brown, grey", "brown", N…
$ skin_color <chr> "fair", "gold", "white, blue", "white", "light", "light", "…
$ eye_color  <chr> "blue", "yellow", "red", "yellow", "brown", "blue", "blue",…
$ birth_year <dbl> 19.0, 112.0, 33.0, 41.9, 19.0, 52.0, 47.0, NA, 24.0, 57.0, …
$ sex        <chr> "male", "none", "none", "male", "female", "male", "female",…
$ gender     <chr> "masculine", "masculine", "masculine", "masculine", "femini…
$ homeworld  <chr> "Tatooine", "Tatooine", "Naboo", "Tatooine", "Alderaan", "T…
$ species    <chr> "Human", "Droid", "Droid", "Human", "Human", "Human", "Huma…
$ films      <list> <"A New Hope", "The Empire Strikes Back", "Return of the J…
$ vehicles   <list> <"Snowspeeder", "Imperial Speeder Bike">, <>, <>, <>, "Imp…
$ starships  <list> <"X-wing", "Imperial shuttle">, <>, <>, "TIE Advanced x1",…



If you use glimpse() after grouping, it tells you tht the data frame is grouped by the specific variables and the number of groups.
You can add multiple groups and they will act in the same way as the count() function - the groups will be the unique combinations of the values in the grouped variables.

grouped <- group_by(.data = starwars, 
                    species, 
                    gender)

glimpse(grouped)

Rows: 87
Columns: 14
Groups: species, gender [42]
$ name       <chr> "Luke Skywalker", "C-3PO", "R2-D2", "Darth Vader", "Leia Or…
$ height     <int> 172, 167, 96, 202, 150, 178, 165, 97, 183, 182, 188, 180, 2…
$ mass       <dbl> 77.0, 75.0, 32.0, 136.0, 49.0, 120.0, 75.0, 32.0, 84.0, 77.…
$ hair_color <chr> "blond", NA, NA, "none", "brown", "brown, grey", "brown", N…
$ skin_color <chr> "fair", "gold", "white, blue", "white", "light", "light", "…
$ eye_color  <chr> "blue", "yellow", "red", "yellow", "brown", "blue", "blue",…
$ birth_year <dbl> 19.0, 112.0, 33.0, 41.9, 19.0, 52.0, 47.0, NA, 24.0, 57.0, …
$ sex        <chr> "male", "none", "none", "male", "female", "male", "female",…
$ gender     <chr> "masculine", "masculine", "masculine", "masculine", "femini…
$ homeworld  <chr> "Tatooine", "Tatooine", "Naboo", "Tatooine", "Alderaan", "T…
$ species    <chr> "Human", "Droid", "Droid", "Human", "Human", "Human", "Huma…
$ films      <list> <"A New Hope", "The Empire Strikes Back", "Return of the J…
$ vehicles   <list> <"Snowspeeder", "Imperial Speeder Bike">, <>, <>, <>, "Imp…
$ starships  <list> <"X-wing", "Imperial shuttle">, <>, <>, "TIE Advanced x1",…


To remove the grouping, use the ungroup() function.
Now you can call functions on the grouped data frame.

title: dplyr Basics
text:
Summarise data with summarise()
The summarise() function summarizes data to one row per grouping. If there are no grouping variables, the output will have a single row summarising all observations.
We can use the n() function to count the number of observations within the group.


summarise(.data = starwars, 
          my_mean = mean(height, na.rm = TRUE), 
          my_sd = sd(height,na.rm = TRUE), 
          total_count = n())

# A tibble: 1 × 3
  my_mean my_sd total_count
    <dbl> <dbl>       <int>
1    175.  34.8          87



Now let’s see what that looks like with the grouped data.


summarise(.data = grouped, 
          my_mean = mean(height, na.rm = TRUE), 
          my_sd = sd(height, na.rm = TRUE), 
          total_count = n())

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'species'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 42 × 5
# Groups:   species [38]
   species   gender    my_mean my_sd total_count
   <chr>     <chr>       <dbl> <dbl>       <int>
 1 Aleena    masculine      79  NA             1
 2 Besalisk  masculine     198  NA             1
 3 Cerean    masculine     198  NA             1
 4 Chagrian  masculine     196  NA             1
 5 Clawdite  feminine      168  NA             1
 6 Droid     feminine       96  NA             1
 7 Droid     masculine     140  52.0           5
 8 Dug       masculine     112  NA             1
 9 Ewok      masculine      88  NA             1
10 Geonosian masculine     183  NA             1
# ℹ 32 more rows

title: Getting Started
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Getting Started
text:
R projects

Opening an R project will open up an RStudio window and change our current directory to the folder the project is saved in.
R projects are meant to store your code, data, and results all in one place. They allow for fast collaboration with others on code, as all files are referenced through relative file paths relative to the project directory. Others will be able to quickly reproduce your work.
I recommend to always use R projects whenever working in R. Using relative file paths (relative to the project directory) such as data/raw_data.csv instead of absolute filepaths like C:/Users/davischr/proj/intro-to-r/data/raw_data.csv can help share code ina more collaborative way - others don’t have to change your code to run it. To reference a folder above the current directory with relative file paths, use ../.

title: Getting Started
text:
Becoming Familiar With RStudio
Let’s take a look around the RStudio GUI.


Console
This is where we can run R code in an interactive session.
R Can do simple mathematical calculations as you would on a calculator.




Environment Pane
This pane will show you what objects you have loaded in memory. More on what these difference objects mean later. You can think of this as our workspace, which is where our objects are saved in memory.




Source pane and R Scripts
The Source pane is where we are able to edit various code-related files, such as R scripts, R Markdown documents, or Quarto documents. For now, we will use R Scripts for our exercises. You can create a new R Script to save the code you have worked on my going to the File > New File > R Script.




Output pane
The Output pane contains many panes; I will highlight three:

Files pane: where you can see files in your working directory and other folders
Plots pane: where graph output can go to view graphs
Help pane: where function descriptions, argument information, and examples are shown. You can get the metadata for functions in R by typing help(<function_name>) or ?<function_name> into the console.










Note



Throughout this course, I will use the <some text here> syntax to refer to text that the user puts in. So, for example, if I write mean(<some object here>), you might type mean(x) or mean(y).

title: Data Frames and tibble
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Data Frames and tibble
text:
Accessing Columns
You can access specific columns in a dataframe by using <dataframe>$<variable> syntax.


iris_abr$Sepal.Length

[1] 5.1 4.9 4.7 4.6 5.0 5.4


You can do the same with the [ , "<col_name"] syntax.

iris_abr[, "Sepal.Length"]

[1] 5.1 4.9 4.7 4.6 5.0 5.4

title: Data Frames and tibble
text:
Subsetting Data Frames
You can remove observations in a data frame similarly to how you would in a vector, with [] and a logical vector.


iris_abr[iris_abr$Sepal.Length < 4.8, ]

  Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species
3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa
4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa



This syntax can be cumbersome, as we need to reference the dataset twice to make it work. We are about to examine a better way of working with data frames.

title: Data Frames and tibble
text:
tidy data
In this class we will be using the tidyverse universe of packages, which are built upon the principles of tidy data.



The core principle is to tidy data into a format that is standardized and more efficient to work with. Then, we use tools optimiszed to work with that kind of data.

title: Data Frames and tibble
text:
Loading tidyverse
For this section, let’s start a script and load the tidyverse package.






Note



Remember, you need to install the packages first in the console by typing install.packages("tidyverse") if you haven’t already. You only need to do this once.




library(tidyverse)

There are many packages within the tidyverse umbrella.

tibble, for tibbles, a modern take on data frames
dplyr, for data manipulation
tidyr, for data tidying
readr, for data import
stringr, for working with strings
forcats, for working with factors (categorical variables with restricted labels)
ggplot2, for data visualization
purrr, for iteration and functional programming


We will be using the tibble and dplyr packages today.

title: Data Frames and tibble
text:
tibble
tibble is a data frame with some slightly adjusted features to make them work better. They:

Never change the type of inputs when they are read in (data frames can for certain inputs)
Print to the console with better user-friendly information
Never creates row.names()
Do not adjust the names of variables

You can convert a dataframe to a tibble with the as_tibble() function.


as_tibble(iris)

# A tibble: 150 × 5
   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species
          <dbl>       <dbl>        <dbl>       <dbl> <fct>  
 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2 setosa 
 2          4.9         3            1.4         0.2 setosa 
 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2 setosa 
 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2 setosa 
 5          5           3.6          1.4         0.2 setosa 
 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4 setosa 
 7          4.6         3.4          1.4         0.3 setosa 
 8          5           3.4          1.5         0.2 setosa 
 9          4.4         2.9          1.4         0.2 setosa 
10          4.9         3.1          1.5         0.1 setosa 
# ℹ 140 more rows



A tibble is a data frame, but not all data frames are necessarily tibbles.

# the class function determines what kind of object the object is 

class(as_tibble(iris))

[1] "tbl_df"     "tbl"        "data.frame"




class(iris)

[1] "data.frame"

title: Exercise 2

title: Exercise 2
text:
Exercise 2.1

panel-tabset


Problem

Part 1: Sort the starwars dataset, descending by height. Assign the new dataset to starwars_1.


Part 2: Based on the values of height, filter() starwars_1 such that it only contains 10 observations. Assign the new dataset to starwars_2.


Part 3: Get the average height in the starwars_2 tibble.







Note



You may need to set na.rm = TRUE in the mean() function.






Solution

Part 1: Sort the starwars dataset, descending, by height. Assign the new dataset to starwars_1.

starwars_1 <- starwars |> 
  arrange(desc(height))



Part 2: Based on the values of height, filter() starwars_1 such that it only contains 10 observations. Assign the new dataset to starwars_2.

starwars_2 <- starwars_1 |> 
  filter(height >= 202)



Part 3: Get the average height in the starwars_2 tibble.

starwars_2 |> 
  summarise(mean_height = mean(height, na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  mean_height
        <dbl>
1        222.



:::

title: Layers
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Layers
text:
Bar Charts
The bar chart is one of the most common data visualizations, which makes it more intuitive for readers as they are able to quickly understand the plot and what it means. There are two ways to create a bar chart in ggplot2.

geom_bar()
geom_bar() makes the height of the bar proportional to the number of cases in each group of the x-axis. In other words, geom_bar() will tabulate frequencies for you based on a categorical variable, without needing to do so yourself, and will visualize those frequencies in a bar chart.


ggplot(diamonds, mapping = aes(color)) + 
  geom_bar(fill = "cornflowerblue")







geom_col()
geom_col(), on the other hand, create the bars based on values within the data for both x and y. To create the above chart with geom_col(), we could use the count() function first to tabulate the data by color from the diamonds data frame. color is the name of a variable in the diamonds data frame that identifies how clear a diamond is in rating.


diamonds |>
  count(color, name = "count") |> # name = just changes the name of the output from n to the value in the quotation marks  
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = color, 
                       y = count)) + 
  geom_col(fill = "cornflowerblue")





I often prefer to use geom_col() because I like to visually see my data when I’m using it. Plus, when using other variables to modify the graph, it is helpful to have a dataset that is at the observation-level that we are visualizing as opposed to the uncounted raw data.



Arranging Bars
One very common visualization need is to arrange the bars in ascending or descending order. We can do so by modifying the data first with forcats::fct_reorder().


diamonds |> 
  count(color, name = "count") |> # tzbulate by color variable 
  mutate(color = fct_reorder(.f = color, 
                             .x = count,
                             .desc = TRUE)) |> # reorder color variable based on the count 
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = color, 
                       y = count)) + # create plot
  geom_col(fill = "cornflowerblue") # visualize bar chart layer







Multiple Categories
We sometimes want to visualize multiple categories on the same graph. For example, in the diamonds dataset, we might want to examine the frequencies of cut by color for only Ideal or Premium cuts.

Stacked Bar Chart
We can do this by adding a fill aesthetic to the graph. We also need to do some data manipulation first to create a count by cut and color. To arrange the graph such that the graph is still descending by color, we also need to add a count by color, which we can do with the group_by() and mutate() functions.


diamonds |> 
  filter(cut %in% c("Ideal", 
                    "Premium")) |> # keep only rows where cut is Ideal or Premium
  count(color, cut, name = "count") |> # tabulate by color and cut, counting by each unique combination
  group_by(color) |> # group by color
  mutate(color_count = sum(count)) |> # aggregate by color, but adding a variable so observation level stays the same
  ungroup() |> # remove grouping
  mutate(color = fct_reorder(.f = color, 
                             .x = color_count, 
                             .desc = TRUE)) |> # reorder color to be descending based on count of color 
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = color, 
                       y = count, 
                       fill = cut)) + # create graph
  geom_col() # plot layer







Stacked Bar Chart, Standardized Vertically
If we wanted a stacked bar chart that represents the proportion of a category made up by another category, we could do this with the position aesthetic.


diamonds |> 
  filter(cut %in% c("Ideal", 
                    "Premium")) |> # keep only rows where cut is Ideal or Premium
  count(color, cut, name = "count") |> # tabulate by color and cut, counting by each unique combination
  group_by(color) |> # group by color
  mutate(color_count = sum(count)) |> # aggregate by color, but adding a variable so observation level stays the same
  ungroup() |> # remove grouping
  mutate(color = fct_reorder(.f = color, 
                             .x = color_count, 
                             .desc = TRUE)) |> # reorder color to be descending based on count of color 
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = color, 
                       y = count, 
                       fill = cut)) + # create graph
  geom_col(position = "fill") # plot layer such that there are standardized bars





We will discuss later how to change the scales to be percent.



Dodged Bar Chart
Let’s say instead we wanted to visualize the genders present in the data frame with colors side by side. We can do this by setting the position aesthetic equal to "dodge".


diamonds |> 
  filter(cut %in% c("Ideal", 
                    "Premium")) |> # keep only rows where cut is Ideal or Premium
  count(color, cut, name = "count") |> # tabulate by color and cut, counting by each unique combination
  group_by(color) |> # group by color
  mutate(color_count = sum(count)) |> # aggregate by color, but adding a variable so observation level stays the same
  ungroup() |> # remove grouping
  mutate(color = fct_reorder(.f = color, 
                             .x = color_count, 
                             .desc = TRUE)) |> # reorder color to be descending based on count of color 
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = color, 
                       y = count, 
                       fill = cut)) + # create graph
  geom_col(position = "dodge") # change position such that it is a chart with side by side columns





If we wanted to reorder the bars such that Ideal goes first, we could use the forcats::fct_rev() function, which reverses the levels in a factor.


diamonds |> 
  filter(cut %in% c("Ideal", 
                    "Premium")) |> # keep only rows where cut is Ideal or Premium
  count(color, cut, name = "count") |> # tabulate by color and cut, counting by each unique combination
  group_by(color) |> # group by color
  mutate(color_count = sum(count)) |> # aggregate by color, but adding a variable so observation level stays the same
  ungroup() |> # remove grouping
  mutate(color = fct_reorder(.f = color, 
                             .x = color_count, 
                             .desc = TRUE)) |> # reorder color to be descending based on count of color 
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = color, 
                       y = count, 
                       fill = fct_rev(cut))) + # create graph with factor reversed
  geom_col(position = "dodge") # change position such that it is a chart with side by side columns

title: Layers
text:
Lollipop Chart
Another way of visualizing bar-chart like data is the lollipop chart. I like this chart when there are a lot of categories, like if we’re using state-level data. We can create a lollipop chart with the geom_segment() and geom_point() functions.


state.x77 |> 
  data.frame() |> # converts this data into a data frame
  rownames_to_column(var = "state") |> # converts the state row names into a column
  mutate(state = fct_reorder(state, Murder)) |> # reorder by Murder so chart is ascending
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = Murder, y = state)) + # create plot with mapped aesthetics of murder rate on x-axis, state on y-axis
  geom_segment(mapping = aes(x = 0,  # create segment that starts at 0
                              xend = Murder, # that ends at the Murder Rate
                              y = state,  # begins at each state
                              yend = state)) + # ends at each state 
  geom_point()

title: Layers
text:
Scatter Plot
We can make a simple scatter plot with geom_point(data = <your data>, mapping = aes(x = <var1>, y = <var2>)).


ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(x = carat, y = price)) + 
  geom_point()

title: Layers
text:
Line Plot
A line plot works similarly to a scatter plot in its construction. Line plots typically display values over a specified time interval. We generally want one line per group we would like to visualize over time, so the data should be constructed in that manner.


# create data

set.seed(0) # set randomization so that this is reproducible 
my_years <- 2000:2020 # create sequential years between 2000 and 2020
random_numbers<- rnorm(n = 21, 
                       mean = 50, 
                       sd = 25) # create random numbers with mean of 50 and sd of 25

# create tibble
my_df <- tibble(my_years, random_numbers)

# line plot

ggplot(data = my_df, mapping = aes(my_years, random_numbers)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_line()

title: Layers
text:
Histograms
We create histograms with the geom_histogram() function.


ggplot(diamonds) + 
  geom_histogram(mapping = aes(carat), 
                 bins = 50) # set number of bins

title: Layers
text:
Density Plots
Relatedly, you can create a density plot with geom_density().


ggplot(diamonds) + 
  geom_density(mapping = aes(carat))

title: Layers
text:
Box Plots
We create box plots with the geom_boxplot() function.


ggplot(diamonds) + 
  geom_boxplot(mapping = aes(x = carat))





If you want to create a box plot by category, you can include the category in one of the axes.


ggplot(diamonds) + 
  geom_boxplot(mapping = aes(x = carat, 
                             y = cut))

title: Exercise 9
text:
Exercise 9.1

ProblemSolution



Install the gapminder package and load it.
Filter the gapminder data frame for rows that have a country of "United States". Assign it to something other than gapminder.
Graph the population of the United States over time using both points and lines.
Increase the size of the points on the graph. Change the shape of the points to "diamond filled". Make the lines blue, the line of the points red, and the inside of the points green. Set the theme to theme_minimal().




Install the gapminder package and load it.



# install.packages("gapminder)  
library(gapminder)



Filter the gapminder data frame for rows that have a country of "United States". Assign it to something other than gapminder.



us <- gapminder |> 
  filter(country == "United States")



Graph the population of the United States over time using both points and lines.



ggplot(data = us, mapping = aes(year, pop)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_line()






Increase the size of the points on the graph. Change the shape of the points to "diamond filled". Make the lines blue, the line of the points red, and the inside of the points green. Set the theme to theme_minimal().


ggplot(data = us, 
       mapping = aes(year, pop)) + 
  geom_point(size = 1, 
             shape = "diamond filled", 
             color = "red", 
             fill = "green") + 
  geom_line(color = "blue") + 
  theme_minimal()

Exercize 9.2 - Challenge

ProblemSolution



Starting with the gapminder data frame, visualize countries in the Americas’ life expectancy over time on the same graph, using the color aesthetic.
Do the same thing, except do not use color to designate individual countries. Find a different way to separate out the groups.




Starting with the gapminder data frame, visuaolize countries in the Americas’ life expectancy over time on the same graph, using the color aesthetic.



gapminder |> 
  filter(continent == "Americas") |> 
  ggplot(mapping = aes(x = year, y = lifeExp, color = country)) +

title: Exercise 7
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Exercise 7
text:
Exercise 7.1

ProblemSolution



Create a scatter plot using the diamonds data frame between carat and depth.
Add mapping = aes(color = cut) inside of the geom_point() function. What does this do?
Remove color=cut and right outside of the aes() function, put , color = "blue". What do you think the difference is from putting an attribute inside the aes() function vs. outside of it? Why would we do each one?
Is there any difference in output between putting color = cut inside of the aes() function within the ggplot() function vs. putting it inside of the aes() function within the geom_point() function?




Create a scatter plot using the diamonds data frame between carat and depth.


ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(x = carat, y = depth)) + 
  geom_point()





Add mapping = aes(color = cut) inside of the geom_point() function. What does this do?


ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(x = carat, y = depth)) + 
  geom_point(mapping = aes(color = cut))




This colors the points by the category cut in the data.

Remove color=cut and right outside of the aes() function, put , color = "blue". What do you think the difference is from putting an attribute inside the aes() function vs. outside of it? Why would we do each one?


ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(x = carat, y = depth)) + 
  geom_point(mapping = aes(), color = "blue")




When the attribute is inside the aes() function, we are trying to map data elements from our data frame onto the plot. When attributes are outside of the aes() function, we are just assigning the value as a constant across all observations. We would do the former if we wanted to color our plot by a category in our data, and we would do the latter if we wanted to assign a color for all observations.

Is there any difference in output between putting color = cut inside of the aes() function within the ggplot() function vs. putting it inside of the aes() function within the geom_point() function?

There is no difference.






Note



This is because subsequent functions have their data and aethstic mappings inherited from the main ggplot() call. However, users could also separately define the data and aesthetic mappings within th elayer functions difrectly. We might do this if we, say, wanted to visualize data from two data frames on the same plot.

title: The ggplot2 package
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: The ggplot2 package
text:
Key Components
The three key components of a ggplot2 plot are data, aesthetic mappings, and layers.

Data
Of course if we are creating a data visualization, we must have data. The data works best with the ggplot2 package if it is in the tidy format.
The first step of creating a plot is the ggplot() function. We often use the data as the first argument in this function.


ggplot(data = diamonds)





By itself, the function only produces a blank plot.


Aesthetic Mappings
Each ggplot plot should have a set of aesthetic mappings that map variables in the data to visual properties, By mapping do not think land map - mapping refers to aligning data to visual properties in graphs.
For example, we might want to map our x axis to carat and our y axis to price from the diamonds data frame.

ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(x = carat, y = price))






           Note that the plot still does not include observation-level data, but the x and y axes are defined. To add data related to observations in a data frame, we must choose a layer to add on to our data.

The columns of our data frame that we want to map to aesthetic features in the aes() function in the mapping argumnet.
<br.


Layers
The layers take the mapped data and display it in a way that humans can understand as a representation of dta. We can think of a layer as determining the geometry by which data are displayed, where a piece of data is displaed, and what kinds of statistical transformations are needed to display the data.


ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(x = carat, y = price)) + 
  geom_point() + # add point layer
  geom_smooth(formula = y ~ x, method = "lm")






           Note the + between functions within a ggplot() call. This is different than a |>, in that the result of the left-hand side is not added as the first argument on the right-hand side. Instead, we use it to add layers, scales, facets, coordaintes, and themes for ggplot objects.






Tip



We will most often be using the geom_*() functions as our layers in this course. Type geom_ into the consoler (after loading tidyverse) and hover over it to see some exmples of geom_*() functions.

title: The ggplot2 package
text:
Additional Features

Scales
Scales are responsible for updating the limits of a plot, setting the breaks, formatting the labels, and possibly applying a transformation.
To use scales, one can use one of the scale functions that are patterned as scale_<aesthetic>_type() functions where <aesthetic> is one of the pairings mde in the mapping part of a plot. For example, to change the y-axis of the graph, we might use the scale_y_continuous() function.

ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(x = carat, y = price)) + 
  geom_point() + #add point layer
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 20000), # set y axis limits
                     breaks = seq(0, 20000, 2000), # set tic marks
                     labels = scales::dollar  # change the format of the labels to show $
                     ) + 
  scale_color_hue()  # add color theme







Facets
Facets can creat multiple plots based on categories or subsets of data. We can quickly split data up to look at relationships within a category or other kinds of patterns.
Facets must be given as a formula, designated by the ~ operator in R.
Let’s plot the same plot from before except using a facet instead of examining cut by color.


ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(x = carat, y = price)) + 
  geom_point() + #add point layer
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 20000), # set y axis limits
                     breaks = seq(0, 20000, 2000), # set tic marks
                     labels = scales::dollar  # change the format of the labels to show $
                     )  + 
  facet_wrap(~cut) # add facet by the cut category







Coordiantes
Coordinates are how the plot interprets position aesthetics. Typically Cartesian coordinates are used, which is what we use for our standard graphs. However, there are other coordinate systems, which we will discuss in more detail next lesson when we start creating geographic maps.
We can use coordinates to flip our x and y axes for the graph. The coord_flip() function flips Cartesian coordinates so that horizontal becomes vertical and vertical, horizontal.
I like this especially for bar charts.


ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(x = cut)) + 
  geom_bar() + 
   scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 20000), # set y axis limits
                     breaks = seq(0, 20000, 2000), # set tic marks
                     labels = scales::dollar  # change the format of the labels to show $
                     )  + 
  coord_flip()

Warning: Removed 1 row containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_bar()`).








Themes
Themes control aspects about visuals for the plot that do not have to do with the data. We can use the themes for a variety of attributes, including location of legends, backbground color for the plot, axes attributes, etc.
We modify theme attributes with the theme() function.


ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(x = cut)) + 
  geom_bar() + 
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 20000), # set y axis limits
                     breaks = seq(0, 20000, 2000), # set tic marks
                     labels = scales::dollar  # change the format of the labels to show $
                     )  + 
  coord_flip() + 
  theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white"), # change background color to white 
        panel.grid.major = element_blank(), # remove grid lines
        panel.grid.minor = element_blank()) # remove grid lines

Warning: Removed 1 row containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_bar()`).






There are also a number of theme_*() functions that essentially have modified many of these options about these attributes already and bundled them into one function.


ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(x = cut)) + 
  geom_bar() + 
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 20000), # set y axis limits
                     breaks = seq(0, 20000, 2000), # set tic marks
                     labels = scales::dollar  # change the format of the labels to show $
                     )  + 
  coord_flip() + # flip the x and y axis
  theme_minimal() # use a minimal theme

Warning: Removed 1 row containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_bar()`).











Note



I am in the process of developing an fhfatheme package for creating visuals with consistent theming across FHFA products created in R. I’ll follow up with everyone when that is released.

title: Introduction to R
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Scales
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Scales
text:
scales_<axis>_continuous()
scale_x_continuous() and scale_y_continuous() modify the x and y axes respectively when we are using variables.
They take in the same parameters.
Some of the most used parameters are:

breaks
limits
labels
expand

ggplot() will create default scales created from the data.

ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(carat, price)) + 
  geom_point()




Let’s see how each parameter might change how the graph looks.

breaks
breaks assigns where tic marks go on scale. Most often we’ll use a numeric vector to specify breaks.

ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(carat, price)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 20000, 2000))






limits
limits cuts off the scale at specified points. Most often we’ll use c(<from>, <to>) syntax to modify limits.

ggplot(data = diamonds, mapping = aes(carat, price)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 20000, 2000), 
                    limits = c(0, 10000))

Warning: Removed 5222 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_point()`).







labels
labels modifies text for the tic marks in the scale. Most often we’ll use scales::percent

title: Introduction to R
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Introduction to R
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Aesthetics
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Aesthetics
text:
x and y

x: The most common aesthetic - the variable that is mapped to the x axis.
y: Variable that is mapped to the y axis. Should usually be present when creating a multivariate plot.



ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data = diamonds, 
             mapping = aes(x = carat, 
                           y = price))

title: Aesthetics
text:
alpha
alpha maps the transparancy of objects. It ranges from a scale of 0 to 1, where lower values correspond to more transparant colors.


ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data = diamonds, 
             mapping = aes(x = carat, 
                           y = price), 
             alpha = .1) # set transparency

title: Aesthetics
text:
color and fill

color maps the color of lines and points (that are not explicit shapes 21-25).
fill: maps the color for inside the lines of polygons (such as bars, geographic maps, etc.)



ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data = diamonds, 
           mapping = aes(x = cut, 
                         fill = cut), # set color within the bar polygon
           color = "red") # set color of lines of the bar polygon





These are the default colors in ggplot2. We will see how to change these defaults when we look at scale_*() functions.

title: Aesthetics
text:
shape
shape changes what an object looks like when visualized, usually for the geom_point() function. Here is a list of possible values.


shape can reference these values as numeric instead, but I won’t supply those here because I do not recommend that - it is better for the reader if you spell out which one you’re using.

title: Aesthetics
text:
size and stroke
The shapes that are filled with red in the graph above have both a color and a fill. The size of the filed part is controlled by size, while the size of the lined part is controlled by stroke.

title: Aesthetics
text:
linetype
linetype can be specified with one of the following character strings:







There are other manual ways to specify how far away each tick is using hexadecimal characters. I will not go over this.

title: Aesthetics
text:
linewidth
linewidth changes the width of a line, go figure.
Due to a historical error, the default value for linewidth is 0.75.
Here’s the default.


# Plot
ggplot(data = my_data, aes(x = xValue, y = yValue)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_line()




Here’s a width of 1.

# Plot
ggplot(data = my_data, aes(x=xValue, y=yValue)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_line(linewidth = 1)





Here’s a width of 2.


# Plot
ggplot(data = my_data, aes(x=xValue, y=yValue)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_line(linewidth = 2)

title: Aesthetics
text:
group
The group aesthetic by default is set to the interaction of all discrete variables in the plot. This usually works correctly, but when it does not, we need to explicitly define the group.
The Oxboys data frame from the nlme package contains the height and age variables, by Subject.


tibble(nlme::Oxboys)

# A tibble: 234 × 4
   Subject     age height Occasion
   <ord>     <dbl>  <dbl> <ord>   
 1 1       -1        140. 1       
 2 1       -0.748    143. 2       
 3 1       -0.463    145. 3       
 4 1       -0.164    147. 4       
 5 1       -0.0027   148. 5       
 6 1        0.247    150. 6       
 7 1        0.556    152. 7       
 8 1        0.778    153. 8       
 9 1        0.994    156. 9       
10 2       -1        137. 1       
# ℹ 224 more rows



However, if you tried to map the height and age variables but not subject, we’d get a wonky graph.


ggplot(nlme::Oxboys, mapping = aes(age, height)) + 
  geom_line()





This looks weird.
We could solve this by incorporating an aesthetic to make every grouping unlie, like color.


ggplot(nlme::Oxboys, mapping = aes(age, height, color = Subject)) + 
  geom_line()





But, if we didn’t want to have different colors for each line, we could use the group parameter instead.


ggplot(nlme::Oxboys, 
       mapping = aes(age, height, group = Subject)) + 
  geom_line()

title: Exercise 8
text:
Exercise 8.1

ProblemSolution



Create two bar graphs of class from the mpg data frame. For one of them, use geom_col() and the other, use geom_bar().
Create three bar graphs of class and trans from the mpg data frame. For one of them, create a stacked graph. For the second, create a graph where the bars for class are the same length. For the last, create a plot where the bars are next to each other, but are colored differently by the second category.




Create two bar graphs of class from the mpg data frame. For one of them, use geom_col() and the other, use geom_bar().


ggplot(data = mpg, mapping = aes(class)) + 
  geom_bar()





mpg |> 
  count(class) |> # count mpg by class
  ggplot(mapping = aes(class, n)) + 
  geom_col()





Create three bar graphs of class and trans from the mpg data frame. For one of them, create a stacked graph. For the second, create a graph where the bars for class are the same length. For the last, create a plot where the bars are next to each other, but are colored differently by the second category.


# Stacked 
 mpg |> 
  count(class, trans) |> 
  ggplot(mapping = aes(class, n, fill = trans)) + 
  geom_col()





# Stacked with same length
mpg |> 
  count(class, trans) |> 
  ggplot(mapping = aes(class, n, fill = trans)) + 
  geom_col(position = "fill")





# Dodged bar chart
mpg |> 
  count(class, trans) |> 
  ggplot(mapping = aes(class, n, fill = trans)) + 
  geom_col(position = "dodge")

title: Exercise 1
text:
Exercise 1.1

ProblemSolution



Create the following vectors:

x: with values 1, 3, 5, 4, 5

y: with values 2, 3, 1, 1, 6

Calculate the length of x. Calculate the length of y.
Calculate the sum of x and y such that each element of x is added to the corresponding element of y.
Print the second elemend of x using an index.
Print that same element using a comparison operator to subset instead. Hint: use the value in the second element.
Print all elements of y less than 3.
Print all elements of x less than 5 and greater than 1.




Create the following vectors:

x: with values 1, 3, 5, 4, 5

y: with values 2, 3, 1, 1, 6




# create x and y

x <- c(1, 
       3, 
       5, 
       4, 
       5)

y <- c(2, 
       3, 
       1, 
       1, 
       6)



Calculate the length of x. Calculate the length of y.


# print length of x
length(x)

[1] 5

# print length of y
length(y)

[1] 5


 - Calculate the sum of x and y such that each element of x is added to the corresponding element of y.

# calculate sum of x and y, vectorized
x + y

[1]  3  6  6  5 11




Print the second elemend of x using an index.



# print second element
x[2]

[1] 3




Print that same element using a comparison operator to subset instead. Hint: use the value in the second element.


# print if x is 3
x[x==3]

[1] 3




Print all elements of y less than 3.


# print if x is less than 3
x[x<3]

[1] 1




Print all elements of x less than 5 and greater than 1.


# print if x is greater than 5 and less than 1
x[x < 5 & x > 1]

[1] 3 4
