Problem

Create a numeric vector z with elements 1, 3, NA, 4, 6, NA.
Remove the missing values within z and print the result.




Solution

Create a numeric vector z with elements 1, 3, NA, 4, 6, NA. 


# create z

z <- c(1, 
       3, 
       NA,
       4,
       6,
       NA)



Remove the missing values within z and print the result.


# remove missing values

z<- z[!is.na(z)]

z

[1] 1 3 4 6

title: Packages and Libraries
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Packages and Libraries
text:
Installing Packages
You can install packages with the install.packages("<package_name>") command. It is recommended that you do so in the console as opposed to writing it in a script (like a .R, .qmd, or .Rmd file). You generally do not want to install a package each time you run a script.

title: Packages and Libraries
text:
Installing tidyverse
Try installing the tidyverse set of packages by typing `install.packages(“tidyverse”) into your console.

title: Packages and Libraries
text:
Loading Packages
You can load packages with library(<package_name>) or library("<package_name>"). Often we go with the former because it’s less typing, but up to you.
Generally, we want to load all packages for a script at the top of the script (or a separate script). This makes the dependencies for a script easier to find in one place. After adding comments describing the purpose of a script, loading packages is generally the first thing we do in a script.







Loading tidyverse



Try loading the tidyverse set of packages by typing library(tidyverse) into your console.



You can reference individual functions in packages without loading the library with the :: operator.


tidyverse::tidyverse_packages()

 [1] "broom"         "conflicted"    "cli"           "dbplyr"       
 [5] "dplyr"         "dtplyr"        "forcats"       "ggplot2"      
 [9] "googledrive"   "googlesheets4" "haven"         "hms"          
[13] "httr"          "jsonlite"      "lubridate"     "magrittr"     
[17] "modelr"        "pillar"        "purrr"         "ragg"         
[21] "readr"         "readxl"        "reprex"        "rlang"        
[25] "rstudioapi"    "rvest"         "stringr"       "tibble"       
[29] "tidyr"         "xml2"          "tidyverse"

title: The pipe operator: |>
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: The pipe operator: |>
The pipe operator: |>
text:
Rewriting our code
We can rewrite our code from before with pipes instead.


starwars |> 
  mutate(height = height / 2 ) |> # add a variable with mutate 
  filter(height < 100) |> # remove observations with filter
  select(height, eye_color, gender) |> # remove columns with select
  arrange(height) |> # sort rows with arrange
  group_by(gender) |> # group data with group by 
  summarise(my_mean = mean(height, na.rm = TRUE)) # aggregate data by group with summarise

# A tibble: 3 × 2
  gender    my_mean
  <chr>       <dbl>
1 feminine     81.6
2 masculine    84  
3 <NA>         87.5


This centers focus for the reader on the functions applied to the input. You can think of the |> as an and then statement. We take the data frame starwars and then we mutate() (add a variable), and then we filter() (remove observations), etc.

title: Welcome
text:
Developed by Christopher Davis





Welcome
 Welcome to the Introduction to R Class!

Step 1: If you haven’t already, please download the class materials from the GitHub Repository.
Step 2: Open up the intro-to-r.Rprojfile to open up the R project related to this class.

title: Vectors
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Vectors
text:
Atomic Vectors
All elements within an atomic vector must have the same type. You can create a vector with the c() function with elements separated by ,.
There are four primary commonly-used atomic vectors.



Source: Advanced R by Wickham




numeric Vectors: integer and double
Like the name denotes, integer vectors all must be whole numbers. double vectors can have any number of decimals.
Most functions we’ll use treat integer vectors and double vectors similarly. For example:


# *digit*L is the way to identify integers in R
integer_vector <- c(2L, 
                    4L, 
                    1L, 
                    3L)

mean(integer_vector)

[1] 2.5



gives the same result as:


# can reference double with just the digits
double_vector <- c(2, 
                   4, 
                   1, 
                   3)

mean(double_vector)

[1] 2.5



For our purposes, we will think of both of these types of vectors as numeric and treat them similarly.


Sorting vectors
You can sort any vector with the sort() function.

sort(double_vector)

[1] 1 2 3 4




numeric vectors in a sequence
To create a numeric vector with sequential numbers, use the syntax <from>:<to>.


# create a sequential numeric vector from 1 to 5
sequential <- 1:5

sequential

[1] 1 2 3 4 5



If you want to increment by smoething else, use the seq() function.
This function takes int he following arguments:


from: starting value

to: ending value

by: increment of the sequence



# create sequence, increment by 3

by_3 <- seq(from = 1, 
            to = 25, 
            by = 3)

by_3

[1]  1  4  7 10 13 16 19 22 25





Arithmetic operators
You can use arthmetic operators with numeric vectors as well as with single elements.
Here is a list of arithmetic operators:






Operator
Name
Example




+
Addition
x + y


-
Subtraction
x - y


*
Multiplication
x * y


/
Division
x / y


^
Exponent
x ^ y


%%
Modulus (Remainder from division)
x %% y


&&
Integer Division
x&&y





Source: W3Schools

These operators are vectorized, which means the operation will occur for each element of the vector.
For example, remember the sequential vector:


# sequence, incremented by 1
sequential

[1] 1 2 3 4 5



We can create a new vector with an arithmetic operator:


# add 1

sequential_plus_1 <- sequential + 1

sequential_plus_1

[1] 2 3 4 5 6



Each element of the vector was changed.
We can also use vectors of the same length on either side of the arithmetic opertor:


character_vector <- c("This", 
                      "is", 
                      "a",
                      "string")

character_vector

[1] "This"   "is"     "a"      "string"


 You can concatenate strings in base R with the paste() function. 

# initialize strings

string_1 <- "This is"
string_2 <- "a string"

# use paste function with multiple strings
paste(string_1, 
      string_2, 
      sep = " ") # use sep argument to add separater between strings

[1] "This is a string"


 You can concatenate strings in the same vector with the collapse argument. 

# concatenate strings in the same vector 
paste(character_vector, collapse = " ")

[1] "This is a string"


 You can count the number of characters in each element of a character vector with the nchar() function. 

# get length of each element
num_chars <- nchar(character_vector)

num_chars

[1] 4 2 1 6


 To get the total number of elements of any vector, you can use the length() function. 

# get length of vector
length_num <- length(num_chars)

length_num

[1] 4






logical Vectors
Logical vectors are limited to binary TRUE and FALSE values.


# this is a logical vector

logical_vector <- c(TRUE, 
                    TRUE, 
                    FALSE, 
                    TRUE)

logical_vector

[1]  TRUE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE



Logical vectors are extremely useful in R, as they can be used to flag and subset values.


Comparison Operators
Comparison opertors are used to compare two values.






Operator
Name
Example




==
Equal
x == y


!=
Not equal
x != y


>
Greater than
x > y


<
Less than
x < y


>=
Greater than or equal to
x >= y


<=
Less than or equal to
x <= y


%in%
Have values within
x %in% y






You can use a comprison of two values, one on each side, and it will provide 1 logical result.


# what values in sequential are equal to 4? 

sequential == 4

[1] FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE FALSE



Or, you can have vectors on both sides.


# my name with old middle initial before marriage 
old_me <- c("Christopher", 
            "W", 
            "Davis")

# my name with new middle initial after marriage

new_me <- c("Christopher", 
            "P", 
            "Davis")

# test what elements are the same 
old_me == new_me

[1]  TRUE FALSE  TRUE


 For this to work correctly, both sides of the comparison must have an equal length().
Other operations work as you might expect.


# test less than operator

values <- c(1, 
            3, 
            2, 
            5, 
            2)

values < 3

[1]  TRUE FALSE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE




# test greater than or equal to operator 

values >= 4

[1] FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE FALSE




The %in% operator
The %in% opertor returns TRUE for each element on the left hand side tht is within an element on the right hand side. It has the same length() as the elements on the left hand side.


# test if each element of sequential is either two or three

values %in% c(2, 3)

[1] FALSE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE






Logical Operators
Logical operators are used to combine conditional statements.











Operator
Name
Example




&
AND operator. Returns TRUE if both elements are TRUE
x == y & a == b


|
OR operator. Returns TRUE if either elements are TRUE
x == y | a == b


!
NOT operator. Returns TRUE if the condition is not TRUE
!(x == y

title: Vectors
text:
Subsetting Vectors
You can pull out an element of a vector with the [] operator.


# create double vector again 
double_vector <- c(2, 
                   4, 
                   1, 
                   3)
# pull out the first element of a vector 
double_vector[1]

[1] 2



You can pull out multiple elements of a vector by providing a vector instead of a number in the [] brackets. These numbers represent the indicies of the vector; i.e., element 1, element 2, element 3, ect.


# create full vector
full_vector <- c(1, 
                 4, 
                 1, 
                 2, 
                 10, 
                 2, 
                 1)

# create vector to represent indicies to pull out 
subset_vector <- c(1, 
                   3,
                   4)

# pull out first, third, and fourth element
full_vector[subset_vector]

[1] 1 1 2



You can also subset with logical vector.


# get only the elements that are equal to 1

full_vector[full_vector == 1]

[1] 1 1 1




# get only the elements that are less than 5

full_vector[full_vector < 5]

[1] 1 4 1 2 2 1

title: Vectors
text:
Missing Values
R represents missing, or unknown, values with NA (short for not applicable). Missing values tend to be infectious: most computations involving a missing value will return another missing value.

some_values_na <- c(2, 
                    NA, 
                    3, 
                    NA,
                    5)

some_values_na < NA

[1] NA NA NA NA NA




some_values_na == NA

[1] NA NA NA NA NA



Therefore, to check if values are missing or not, use the is.na() function.


is.na(some_values_na)

[1] FALSE  TRUE FALSE  TRUE FALSE

title: Vectors
text:
Type Assessment

typeof() function
You can check what type an atomic vector is with the typeof() function.

# get type of vector

typeof(double_vector)

[1] "double"



# get type of vector

typeof(character_vector)

[1] "character"



# get type of vector

typeof(logical_vector)

[1] "logical"




is_<type> functions
We sometimes wnt to be able to identify whether variables are numeric, character, or logical. We can do this with the is_<type>() functions.


numeric_vector <- c(3, 
                    5, 
                    1, 
                    7, 
                    2)

is.numeric(numeric_vector)

[1] TRUE




character_vector <- c(3, 
                      5, 
                      1, 
                      "not a number")

is.character(character_vector)

[1] TRUE








Note



When both character elements and numeric elements are put into the c() function, it evaluates to a character vector.

title: Vectors
text:
Type Conversion
One fucntionality we have not talked about in R is when we want to convert from one kind of variable to another. We can do this with the as.numeric(), as.character(), andas.logical()` functions.

as.character(numeric_vector)

[1] "3" "5" "1" "7" "2"



as.numeric(character_vector)

Warning: NAs introduced by coercion


[1]  3  5  1 NA








Note



When converting from character to numeric, if there is an element with at least one character that would not evaluate to a numeric, that element is cast to NA (missing).

title: Untitled
text:
Lesson 01 - Data Wrangling 1

Getting Started

help() : Opens up help documentation for packages and functions. ?<function_name> does the same.



R Basics.

\<- : Assign a value to a name.



Vectors.

c() : Generic function which combines its arguments. The default method combines its arguments to form a vector. All arguments are coerced to a common type which is the type of the returned value, and all attributes except names removed.
mean() : Generic function for the (trimmed) arithmetic mean.
sort() : Sort (or order) a vector or factor into ascending or descending order.
<from>:<to> : Generate regular sequences.
seq() : Generate regular sequences (with more options than :).
paste() : Concatenate vectors after converting to character.
nchar() : Takes a character vector as an argument and returns a vector whose elements contain the sizes of the corresponding elements of x.
length() : Get or set the length of vectors (including lists) and factors, and of any other R object for which a method has been defined.
[] : Operator that acts on vectors, matrices, arrays, and lists to extract or replace parts.
NA : NA is a logical constant of length ` which contains a missing value indicator.
is.na() : Indicates which elements of a vector are missing. Returns TRUE if missing, otherwise FALSE.
typeof() : Determined the (R internal) type or storage mode of any object.
is.numeric() : Determines if a vector is of a class numeric or not.
is.logical() : Determines if a vector is of type logical or not.
is.character() : Determines if a vector is of type character or not.
as.numeric() : Converts vector to numeric.
as.logical() : Converts vector to logical.
as.character() : Converts vector to character.


Arithmetic Operators
You can use arithmetic operators with numeric vectors as well as with single elements.
Here is a list of arithmetic operators:






Operator
Name
Example




+
Addition
x + y


-
Subtraction
x - y


*
Multiplication
x * y


/
Division
x / y


^
Exponent
x ^ y


%%
Modulus (Remainder from division)
x %% y


&&
Integer Division
x&&y





Source: W3Schools


Comparison Operators
Comparison operators are used to compare two values.






Operator
Name
Example




==
Equal
x == y


!=
Not equal
x != y


>
Greater than
x > y


<
Less than
x < y


>=
Greater than or equal to
x >= y


<=
Less than or equal to
x <= y


%in%
Have values within
x %in% y








Logical Operators
Logical operators are used to combine conditional statements.











Operator
Name
Example




&
AND operator. Returns TRUE if both elements are TRUE
x == y & a == b


|
OR operator. Returns TRUE if either elements are TRUE
x == y | a == b


!
NOT operator. Returns TRUE if the condition is not TRUE
!(x == y









Packages and Libraries


install.packages() : Download and install packages from CRAN-like repositories or from local files.
library() : Attach add-on packages.
:: : Accessing exported and internal variables i.e. R objects (including lazy loaded datasets) in a namespace.




Data Frames and tibble


head() : Returns the first or last parts of a vector, matrix, table, data frame, or function.
tibble::as_tibble() : Turns an existing object, such as a data frame or matrix, into a so-called tibble, a data frame with class tbl_df.
class() : For objects which have a formal class, its name is returned. R posseses a simple generic function mechanism which can be used for an object-oriented style of programming.




dplyr Basics


dplyr::glimpse() : Prints information about a data frame or tibble to the console.
dplyr::mutate() : Creates new columns that are functions of existing variables. It can also modify (if the name is the same as an existing column) and delete columns (by setting their value to NULL).
dplyr::filter() : Used to subset a data frame, retaining all rows that satisfy your conidtions. To be retained, the row must produce a value of TRUE for all conditions. Note that when a condition evaluates to NA the row will be dropped, unlike base subsetting with [.
dplyr::select() : Select (and optionally rename) variables in a data frame, using a concise mini-language that makes it easy to refer to varaibles based on their name (e.g. <a>:<f> selects all columns from a on the left to f on the right) or type (e.g. where(is.numeric) selects all numeric columns).
tidyselect::everything() : Selects all variables. It is also useful in ocmbination with other tidyselect operators.
dplyr::arrange() : Orders the rows of a dta frame by the values of selected columns.
dplyr::count() : Lets you quickly count the unique values of one or more variables.
dplyr::group_by() : Most data operations are done on groups defined by variables. group_by() takes an existing tbl and converts it into a grouped tbl where operations are performed “by group”.
dplyr::ungroup() : Removes grouping.
dplyr::summarise() : Returns on row for each combination of grouping variables; if there are no grouping variables, the output will have a single row summarasing all ovservations in the input. It will contain one column for each grouping variable and one column for each of the summary statistics that you have specified. summarise() and summarize() are synonyms.



The pipe operator: |>

|> : Passes, or pipes, the result of the left-hand side expression to the right-hand side expression. If the right-hand side expression is a function call, then the left-hand-side is inserted as the first argument in the call.

title: Untitled
text:
Lesson 02 - Data Wrangling 2

Data Import and Export

readr::read_csv(): Read in .csv files.
readxl::read_excel(): Read in .xlsx or .xls files.
haven::read_sas() : Read in .sas7bdat or .sas7bcat files.
haven::read_xpt() : Read in SAS trasnfer files (.xpt).
haven::read_stata() : Read in .dta files.
readRDS() : Read in native .RDS files.
arrow::read_feather() : Read in .feather files.
arrow::read_parquet() : Read in .parquet files.
[data.table::fread()](https://www.rdocumentation.org/packages/data.table/versions/1.15.0/topics/fread) : Read in.csv` files faster.
readxl::excel_sheets() : Read in excel sheets form a .xlsx or .xls file.
readr::write_csv() : Write out .csv files.
haven::write_sas() : Write out .sas7bdat or .sas7bcat files.
haven::write_dta() : Write out .dta files.
saveRDS() : Save native .RDS files.
arrow::write_feather(): Write out .feather files.
arrow::write_parquet(): Write out .parqeut files.
janitor::clean_names() : Clean up messy variable names.
dplyr::if_else() : Takes in logical condition - if TRUE, output the value in the true argument, otherwise output the value in the false argument.
dplyr::case_when() : Takes in multiple logical conditions - basically use when you want to do multiple if/else statements. Each case is evaluated sequentially and the first match for each element determines the correspending value in the output vector.
stringr::str_c() : Concatenates a string.
stringr::str_length() : Provides the length of each element of a string.
dplyr::pull() : Extracts a clumn from a data frame.

stringr::str_detect() : Returns TRUE if pattern is matched in string. `FALSE`` otherwise.
stringr::str_pad() : Pads a string to be a specified width.
stringr::str_trim() : Removes whitespace from the start or end of a string.
stringr::str_sub() : Subset a string based on indices.
stringr::str_to_lower() : Converts strings to lower case (asdfjl).
stringr::str_to_upper() : Converts strings to upper case (ASDFJL).
stringr::str_to_title() : Converts strings to title case (This Is A Title).
stringr::str_to_sentence() : Converts strings to sentence case (This is a sentence.).



Attributes

attributes() : Returns the attributes of an R object.
names() : Returns the names attribute within an R object. Can also assign with names(x)<-.
class() : Returns the S3 object class of an R object.
factor() : Creates a factor variable.
as.Date() : Converts character or numeric to the Date class.
lubridate::ymd() : Flexibly convert data to Date, with format “year”, “month”, “day”.
lubridate::ydm() : Flexibly convert data to Date, with format “year”, “day”, “month”.
lubridate::myd() : Flexibly convert data to Date, with format “month”, “year”, “day”.
lubridate::mdy() : Flexibly convert data to Date, with format “month”, “day”, “year”.
lubridate::dmy() : Flexibly convert data to Date, with format “day”, “month”, “year”.
lubridate::dym() : Flexibly convert data to Date, with format “dau”, “year”, “month”.
lubridate::year() : Extract year from date.
lubridate::month() : Extract month from date.
lubridate::day() : Extract day from date.
lubridate::wday() : Extract weekday from date.
lubridate::quarter() : Extract quarter from date.



Reshaping Data

tidyr::pivot_longer(): Reshapes data longer.
tidyr::pivot_wider : Reshapes data wider.



Combining Data Frames

dplyr::bind_rows() : Appends data frames together.
dplyr::bind_cols() : Joins toether by column with no keys. Not recommended under most conditions.
dplyr::inner_join : Joins together by key, returns obsevation if key is present on both sides.
dplyr::full_join : Joins together by key, returns observation if key is present on either side.
dplyr::left_join : Joins together by key, returns observation if key is present on left side.
dplyr::right_join : Joins together by key, returns observation if key is present on right side.
dplyr::join_by() : Helper function for assigning by within join functions.



Lesson 03 - Data Visualization 1

The ggplot2 package

ggplot2::ggplot() : Initializes a ggplot object and creates an empty plot. Can also optionally set aesthetics that are inherited by later functions.
ggplot2::aes() : Aesthetic mappings describe how variables in the data are mapped to visual properties of geoms. Set in ggplot() and individaul layers.
ggplot2::geom_point() : Layer used to create scatterplots or points on a line graph.
ggplot2::geom_smooth() : Layer used to create a trend line over an existing plot.
ggplot2::scale_<axis>_continuous() : Scale used with continuous axis can set limits, breaks, and labels (among other things).
ggplot2::scale_<color or fill>_hue() : Maps each elvel to an evenly spaced hue on the color wheel.
ggplot2::facet_wrap() : Graphs multiple panels of data in a rectangular strcuture. Use a <var> syntax to generate panels by <var>.
ggplot2::geom_bar() : Layer that creates a bar plot with one varaible.
ggplot2::coord_flip() : Flips the X and Y axes.
ggplot2::theme() : Customize non-data components of plot.
ggplot2::element_rect() : Modify rectangular theme element.
ggplot2::element_blank() : Remove element from theme.
ggplot2::theme_minimal() : Complete theme that draws minimal lines and ticks.




Layers

ggplot2::geom_col() : Layer that creates a bar plot with two variables (minimum).
forcats::fct_reorder() : Reorders a factor on the order of another variable.
ggplot2::geom_segment() : Layer that draws a straight line between points. We can use it with geom_point() to create a lollipop chart.
ggplot2::geom_line() : Layer that creates a line graph.
ggplot2::geom_histogram() : Layer that creates a histogram.
ggplot2::geom_density() : Layer that creates a density plot.
ggplot2::geom_boxplot() : Layer that creates a box plot.



Aesthetics
No new functions! See the Aesthetic specifics ggplot2 vignette.


Scales

ggplot2::expansion() : Generate scale expansion vectors for the expand argument in a scale.
ggplot2::scale_y_reverse() : Transform y axis from high to low instead of low to high.
ggplot2::scale_<aesthetic>_manual() : Scale that allows you to specific mappings from levels in the data to aesthetic values (like colors).
ggplot2::scale_<color or fill>_brewer() : Maps values in data to an existing color pallete.



Text and Annotations

ggplot2::labs() : Modify axis, legend, and plot labels.
ggplot2::geom_text() : Layer that adds text from the data. No rectangle present behind text.
ggplot2::geom_label() : Layer that adds text from the data. Rectangle present behind text.
dplyr::slice() : Filtrs rows by their integer index locations.
ggplot2::annotate() : Add text (or another geom) to a graph not stemming from the data.



Themes

ggplot2::theme_gray() : This is the default ggplot2 complete theme that we’ve already seen.
ggplot2::theme_bw() : A dark on-light ggplot2 theme, which may work better for presentations displayed with a projecter.
ggplot2::theme_linedraw() : Another dark-on-light ggeplot2 theme, which may work better for presentations displayed with an old-timey projecter.
ggplot2::theme_light() : Light theme. Because of its light grey lines and axes, it focuses more attention on the data.
ggplot2::theme_dark() : Similar to theme_light() but the dark version. Good if you want to show colors with a dark background.
ggplot2::theme_minimal : A minimilastic theme. I quite like minimalistic themes as we focus more on the data.
ggplot2::theme_classic() : Also a minimalistic theme, with solid axes but no gridlines.
ggplot2::theme_void() : A completely empty theme. Good if you don’t want any axes or gridlines.

Other Data Visualization Packages

title: Untitled
text:
Functions and Iteration

Creating Functions

set.seed() : Sets a random number state such that randomly created numbers can be created in a reproducible manner.
rnorm() : Creates random numbers with n, mean, and standard deviation that follow a normal distribution.
function() : Defines new functions in the R language.
return() : returns an output within a function, exiting the function.
if() : checks if condition is TRUE, if so evaluates next statement.
else()) : after an if statement, this function will evaluate the proceeding expression if the preceding expression is FALSE
stop() : throws an error with an error message.
warning() : throws a warning with a warning message.



Working with Multiple Columns

dplyr::across() : applies a function across multiple columns in a data frame within a mutate() or summarise() function.
tidyselect::everything() : Matches all variables in a selection.
tidyselect::starts_with() : Matches columns that start with a specific prefix.
tidyselect::ends_with() : Matches columns that end with a specific suffix.
tidyselect::contains() : Matches columns that contain a specific string.
tidyselect::matches() : Matches a regular expression (see page 2 of the stringr cheat sheet)
<from:<to> : for selecting a range of consecutive variables. <from> and <to> can be numeric indicies of the position of the column or variable names (e.g.; carat:clarity).
! : (in selection context), for taking all variables but the ones identified afterwards (e.g.: !carat:clarity would identify all variables but those between and including carat and clarity positionally in the dataframe).
c() : (in selection context) combine selections together.
tidyselect::all_of() and tidyselect::any_of() : Matches variable names given a character vector. These are the same except no error is thrown for any_of() if names don’t exist, but an error is thrown for all_of().
tidyselect::where() : applies a function to all varaibles and selects those for which the function returns TRUE.
dplyr::rename_with() : renames columns using a function.
dplyr::if_any() : apply the same function to a selection of columns and combine the result into a single logical vector. if_any() returns TRUE when the predicate is TRUE for any of the selected columns.
dplyr::if_all() : apply the same function to a selection of columns and combine the result into a single logical vector. if_all() returns TRUE when the predicate is TRUE for all of the selected columns.
list.files() : produces a character vector of the files in the specified directory.
purrr::map() : transform input by applying a function to each element of a list or atomic vector. Always returns a list.
purrr::list_rbind() : combines list elements into a data frame by row-binding them together.
readr::parse_number() : extracts the first number it finds, dropping any non numeric characters before and after.
rlang::set_names() : sets the names on an object and returns the object.
basename() : removes all of the path up to and including the last path separator.
purrr::walk() : calls a function but does not return an output.
purrr::walk2() : calls a function that does not return an output with two inputs of the same length.
purrr::map2() : calls a function that returns a list object with two inputs of the same length.

title: Exercise 6
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Exercise 6
text:
Exercise 6.1

Problem



Install the nycflights13 package and load it.
The flights data frame in that package records data related to flights, like their departure time, their scheduled departure time, distance between airports, etc. The planes data frame records data about each plane. Identify the shared key among these two datasets.
Do a join such that all records on both sides end up in the result, even if there is no complementing key for it in on the other data frame. Assign the result to joined.
Note that there are now the variables year.x and year.y in the data frame. Why might this be the case? ### Solution
Install the nycflights13 package and load it.



# run in the console
install.packages("nycflights13")

# load the library
library(nycflights13)



The flights data frame in that package records data related to flights, like their departure time, their scheduled departure time, distance between airports, etc. The planes data frame records data about each plane. Identify the shared key among these two datasets.

The shared key is tailnum. It occurs in both data frames and has the same format.

Do a join such that all records on both sides end up in the result, even if there is no complementing key for it in on the other data frame. Assign the result to joined.



joined <- full_join(flights, planes, join_by(tailnum))



Note that there are now the variables year.x and year.y in the data frame. Why might this be the case? 

year exists in both data frames but was not included in the by condition because they reference different years. Unlike SAS, in R when you merge two data frames that have the same variable, the variables are renamed with suffixes and are both maintained in teh result.

title: Exercise 6
text:
Exercise 6.2 - Challenge
::: panel-tabset

Problem

Load the tidylog package and do the join again. How many observations did we not find a key for on each side?
With the results of 6.1 (joined), identify the manufacturer for the plane of the flight that occurs first temporally in the data frame.
Look up the semi_join() and anti_join() function documentation.
Under what circumstances would you use these functions?



Solution

Load the tidylog package and do the join again. How many observations did we not find a key for on each side?


library(tidylog)


joined <- full_join(flights, planes, join_by(tailnum))

full_join: added 9 columns (year.x, year.y, type, manufacturer, model, …)
           > rows only in flights   52,606
           > rows only in planes         0
           > matched rows          284,170
           >                      =========
           > rows total            336,776



52,606 observations in flights do not have a record in planes but 0 records in planes do not have a record in flights.


With the results of 6.1 (joined), identify the manufacturer for the plane of the flight that occurs first temporally in the data frame.



joined |> 
  arrange(year.x, 
          month, 
          day, 
          dep_time) |> 
  head(1) |> 
  pull(manufacturer)

[1] "BOEING"




Look up the semi_join() and anti_join() function documentation.



help(semi_join)
help(anti_join)



Under what circumstances would you use these functions?

semi_join() - When you want to filter a data frame based on if a key exists in another data frame.
anti_join() - When you want to filter a dataframe based on if a key does not exist in another data frame. :::

title: Attributes
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Attributes
text:
Names
Any vector can have the names attribute added onto it. 

# create numeric vector

numeric_vector <- c(2, 
                    4, 
                    6, 
                    1, 
                    2)

# assign names to numeric vector
names(numeric_vector) <- c("these", 
                           "names", 
                           "are", 
                           "arbitrarily", 
                           "given")

# print numeric vector
numeric_vector

      these       names         are arbitrarily       given 
          2           4           6           1           2 


 We can see that the names attribute was added for tht vector. 

attributes(numeric_vector)

$names
[1] "these"       "names"       "are"         "arbitrarily" "given"      


 For data frames, the names attribute represents the column names of the data frame.

title: Attributes
text:
Class
Class is used to implement the S3 object oriented system and identifies the kind of S3 object an object is. Objects are able to be used in functions to behave differently for different classes of input and generally share characterstics between objects of the same class. I won’t go too much into object-oriented programmin gin this course due to time constraints.
We’ve already worked with some objects that have formal classes, like data frames and tibbles.


class(starwars)

[1] "tbl_df"     "tbl"        "data.frame"

title: Attributes
text:
Augmented Vectors
Atomic vectors are the building blocks for other important vector types like factors and dates. These augmented vectors have a class, so they behave differently than the atomic vector on which they are built.

Factors
Factors are designed to represent categorical data. They take a fixed set of possible values that can be ordered or unordered.
They are built on top of integer (not character).
Here’s an example from Hadley Wickam’s R for Data Science.


# create factor
x <- factor(c("ab", "cd", "ab"), levels = c("ab", "cd", "ef"))

# get type of variable
typeof(x)

[1] "integer"

# get attributes of variable 
attributes(x)

$levels
[1] "ab" "cd" "ef"

$class
[1] "factor"


 The levels attribute identifies the unique values the factor can have. We see that the class is of type factor.
Factors are important when we want to limit categorical variables to having only certin values, or when we want to arrnage a variable by a particular set of levels.
To take another example from Mr. Wickham: 

# set unique month levels in order
month_levels <- c("Jan", 
                  "Feb", 
                  "Mar", 
                  "Apr", 
                  "May", 
                  "Jun", 
                  "Jul", 
                  "Aug", 
                  "Sep", 
                  "Oct", 
                  "Nov", 
                  "Dec")

# create character vector
x1 <- c("Dec", "Apr", "Jan", "Mar")

# convert character vector to factor
y1 <- factor(x1, levels = month_levels)

# print factor
y1

[1] Dec Apr Jan Mar
Levels: Jan Feb Mar Apr May Jun Jul Aug Sep Oct Nov Dec

# print sorted factor 
sort(y1)

[1] Jan Mar Apr Dec
Levels: Jan Feb Mar Apr May Jun Jul Aug Sep Oct Nov Dec


 Any values not in the set will be converted to NA. 

# create factor with noncorming input
factor(c("Jan", "Not Jan"), 
       levels = month_levels)

[1] Jan  <NA>
Levels: Jan Feb Mar Apr May Jun Jul Aug Sep Oct Nov Dec


 Factors will be especially helpful in data visualization, which we will be doing later in this course. 


Dates
Dates are another common extension of an atomic vector. Dates are built upon numeric vectors. 

before <- as.Date("1969-01-01")

typeof(before)

[1] "double"

attributes(before)

$class
[1] "Date"




lubridate package
The lubridate package has a bunch of functions to more easily work with Dates in R.
The ymd(), ydm(), mdy(), myd(), dmy(), and dym() functions all flexibly take in a wide variety of input formats bsed on the function, where y means year, m means month, and d means day. 

mdy("April 10th, 2024")

[1] "2024-04-10"

mdy("Wednesday, 04-10-2024")

[1] "2024-04-10"

ymd("2024/04/10")

[1] "2024-04-10"


 Once a vector has been converted to a date object, we can then use functions like:

year(): extract year from date
month(): extract month from date
day(): extract day from date
wday(): extract weekday from date
quarter(): extract quarter from date

to extract what we need from a date.

title: Reshaping Data
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Reshaping Data
text:
Reshaping data
Let’s take a look at the following data frame.


table_1

# A tibble: 6 × 4
  state       year  units population
  <chr>      <dbl>  <dbl>      <dbl>
1 Alabama     1990 139046    1119918
2 Alabama     2000 139163    1531404
3 California  1990 128574    1328816
4 California  2000 119428    1198167
5 Wyoming     1990 139871    1233838
6 Wyoming     2000 104444    1135912



Each column represents a distinct point of informtion and each ovservation represents a state at given point in time.
But, what if the data looked like this instead? 

table_2

# A tibble: 12 × 4
   state       year name         value
   <chr>      <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>
 1 Alabama     1990 units       139046
 2 Alabama     1990 population 1119918
 3 Alabama     2000 units       139163
 4 Alabama     2000 population 1531404
 5 California  1990 units       128574
 6 California  1990 population 1328816
 7 California  2000 units       119428
 8 California  2000 population 1198167
 9 Wyoming     1990 units       139871
10 Wyoming     1990 population 1233838
11 Wyoming     2000 units       104444
12 Wyoming     2000 population 1135912



What if we had units data that looked like this?


table_3

# A tibble: 3 × 3
  state      `1990` `2000`
  <chr>       <dbl>  <dbl>
1 Alabama    139046 139163
2 California 128574 119428
3 Wyoming    139871 104444

title: Reshaping Data
text:
pivot_*() functions
We can use the pivot_wider() and pivot_longer() functions to reshape wide and long.

pivot_wider()
The pivot_wider() function can tqke in the names_from argument and the values_from argument. The column(s) we put in names_from will be the column names of the new data, nd the column(s) we put in values_from will be the values.


table_2

# A tibble: 12 × 4
   state       year name         value
   <chr>      <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>
 1 Alabama     1990 units       139046
 2 Alabama     1990 population 1119918
 3 Alabama     2000 units       139163
 4 Alabama     2000 population 1531404
 5 California  1990 units       128574
 6 California  1990 population 1328816
 7 California  2000 units       119428
 8 California  2000 population 1198167
 9 Wyoming     1990 units       139871
10 Wyoming     1990 population 1233838
11 Wyoming     2000 units       104444
12 Wyoming     2000 population 1135912



table_2 |> 
  pivot_wider(names_from = name, 
              values_from = value)

# A tibble: 6 × 4
  state       year  units population
  <chr>      <dbl>  <dbl>      <dbl>
1 Alabama     1990 139046    1119918
2 Alabama     2000 139163    1531404
3 California  1990 128574    1328816
4 California  2000 119428    1198167
5 Wyoming     1990 139871    1233838
6 Wyoming     2000 104444    1135912





pivot_longer()
The pivot_longer() function can take in the columnst hat we want to reshape long with the cols argumnet. You can also supply the names_to argument to provide the name of the column tht held the data in the names (in our case year), and the values_to argument to give a names to the column for the values.


table_3 

# A tibble: 3 × 3
  state      `1990` `2000`
  <chr>       <dbl>  <dbl>
1 Alabama    139046 139163
2 California 128574 119428
3 Wyoming    139871 104444

table_3 |> 
  pivot_longer(cols = c(`1990`, 
                        `2000`), 
               names_to = "year", 
               values_to = "units")

# A tibble: 6 × 3
  state      year   units
  <chr>      <chr>  <dbl>
1 Alabama    1990  139046
2 Alabama    2000  139163
3 California 1990  128574
4 California 2000  119428
5 Wyoming    1990  139871
6 Wyoming    2000  104444









Note



Because the variable names for table_3 are invalid names, you need to use the ` keys to access them. These are the unshifted version of the ~ character.



Here’s a more complicated pivot_longer() use case.

table_4

# A tibble: 3 × 5
  state      population_1990 population_2000 units_1990 units_2000
  <chr>                <dbl>           <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl>
1 Alabama            1119918         1531404     139046     139163
2 California         1328816         1198167     128574     119428
3 Wyoming            1233838         1135912     139871     104444



To pivot this long, we can use the names_sep argument to identify that information is being stored in our columns in two places, and that they are separated by the _ character.

table_4 |> 
  pivot_longer(cols = -state, # select all columns minus the state
               names_to = c("variable", "year"),  # multiple column names to convert to
               values_to = "value",  # what to name column with values
               names_sep = "_") # separator for current variable names

# A tibble: 12 × 4
   state      variable   year    value
   <chr>      <chr>      <chr>   <dbl>
 1 Alabama    population 1990  1119918
 2 Alabama    population 2000  1531404
 3 Alabama    units      1990   139046
 4 Alabama    units      2000   139163
 5 California population 1990  1328816
 6 California population 2000  1198167
 7 California units      1990   128574
 8 California units      2000   119428
 9 Wyoming    population 1990  1233838
10 Wyoming    population 2000  1135912
11 Wyoming    units      1990   139871
12 Wyoming    units      2000   104444


We can then pivot it back to a tidy dataset using pivot_wider().

table_4 |>
    pivot_longer(cols = -state, # select all columns minus the state
               names_to = c("variable", "year"),  # multiple column names to convert to
               values_to = "value",  # what to name column with values
               names_sep = "_" # separator for current variable names
    ) |> 
  pivot_wider(names_from = variable, # column for where the names will come from for new columns
              values_from = value) # column for where values will come from 

# A tibble: 6 × 4
  state      year  population  units
  <chr>      <chr>      <dbl>  <dbl>
1 Alabama    1990     1119918 139046
2 Alabama    2000     1531404 139163
3 California 1990     1328816 128574
4 California 2000     1198167 119428
5 Wyoming    1990     1233838 139871
6 Wyoming    2000     1135912 104444


```

title: Exercise 4
text: Developed by Christopher Davis

title: Exercise 4
text:
Exercise 4.1

ProblemSolution



Read in data at “lesson_code/02_lesson/data/alabama_fips.csv” and assign to alabama.
Create a variable in alabama called alpha_type that is “Low Alphabetically” if the county_code is <= 65 and “High Alphabetically” otherwise. Overwrite alabama.
Fix the leading zeros in state_code and county_code with str_pad().
Create the full county code by concatenating the 2-digit state code and 3-digit county code. Call the new variable geoid.




Read in data at “lesson_code/02_lesson/data/alabama_fips.csv” and assign to alabama.



alabama <- read_csv("lesson_code/02_lesson/data/alabama_fips.csv")



Create a variable in alabama called alpha_type that is “Low Alphabetically” if the county_code is <= 65 and “High Alphabetically” otherwise. Overwrite alabama.


alabama <- alabama |> 
  mutate(alpha_type = if_else(county_code <= 65, 
                              "Low Alphabetically", 
                              "High Alphabetically"))



Fix the leading zderios in state_code and county_code with str_pad().


alabama <- alabama |> 
  mutate(state_code = str_pad(state_code, 
                              2, 
                              "left", 
                              "0"), 
         county_code = str_pad(county_code, 
                               3, 
                               "left", 
                               "0"))



Create the full county code by concatenating the 2-digit state code and 3-digit county code. Call the new variable geoid.


alabama <- alabama |> 
  mutate(geoid = str_c(state_code, county_code))

alabama

title: Exercise 4
text:
Exercise 4.2 - Challenge

ProblemSolution



Read in the alabama dataset anew.
Create your own binned categories based on the county_code (alphabetically). Use at least 4 bins. Call the varaible alpha_type_2. Make sure no missing data is created.
Count the frequency of alpha_type_2.




Read in the alabama dataset anew.



alabama <- read_csv("lesson_code/02_lesson/data/alabama_fips.csv")



Create your own binned categories based on the county_code (alphabetically). Use at least 4 bins. Call the varaible alpha_type_2. Make sure no missing data is created.



alabama <- alabama |> 
  mutate(
    alpha_type_2 = case_when(
      county_code < 34 ~ "Very Low", 
      county_code >= 34 & county_code < 68 ~ "Medium Low", 
      county_code >= 68 & county_code < 102 ~ "Medium High", 
      county_code >= 102 ~ "Very High"
    ))



Count the frequency of alpha_type_2.



alabama |> 
  count(alpha_type_2)

title: Data Import and Export
text:
Packages
In this section, we will be using:

readr: part of tidyverse, for plain text files (.csv)

data.table: for large .csv files
haven: for SAS (.sas7bdat, .sas7bcat) and Stata (.dta) files

arrow: for .feather and .parquet files.








Tip



Remember if you do not have these packages installed, call install.packages("<package_name>") in the console. Load them in scripts or the console with library(<package_name>).

title: Data Import and Export
text:
Reading in data
In general, many of the functions used to read in data in R will have the read prefix.

read::read_csv(): read in .csv files
readxl::read_excel(): read in .xlsx or .xls files
haven::read_sas() read in .sas7bdat or .sas7bcat files
haven::read_stata(): read in .dta files
readRDS(): read in native .RDS files
arrow::read_feather(): read in .feather files
arrow::read_parquet(): read in .parquet files

The data.table::fread() function is also available for readin gin large .csv files relatively fast.


R paths
There are a few things you should know about paths in R.

With R paths, you must use / slashes to indicate folders within a path, not \.
You can reference up a directory using relative file paths with ../.
You can change your current directory with the setwd("<path>") function. I recommend not to do this, as it makes it more difficult to collaborate with others. Use getwd() to see your current directory (or look at the top of the console).
Each of the read_* functions has arguments that can help read in the data. For example, some allow you to skip rows when reading in, only read in certain columns, set column types, and more.




Reading .csv files
For the simplest use cases, the various read functions will need just one argument: the path to the file you want to load.


sepal <- read_csv("data/iris.csv")

 
I encourage the use of relative filepaths like this, but you could use the aboslute file path if you would like as well.


sepal <- read_csv("C:/Users/christopherdavis/intro-to-r/lesson_code/02_lesson/data/iris.csv")


We can now work with this data frame as we would any other.


sepal |> 
  filter(Species == "setosa")



Reading large .csv files
One function that may help speed up reading in large .csv files is the data.table::fread() function. It uses C++ under the hood to optimize reading in the data.


sas_dat <- read_sas("Data/UADAggs_nat_V3_0.sas7bdat")
stata_dat <- read_stata("data/UADAggs_nat_V3_0.dta")


You can also read in xpt SAS transfer files.


xpt_dat <- read_xpt("data/UADAggs_nat_V3_0.xpt")





Reading Excel Files
Reading in Excel files is a little more complicated because there are sometimes more than one sheet to work with.
To find out the excel sheets in a particular excel file, use the readxl::excel_sheets() function.


excel_path <- "data/cars.xlsx"

my_sheets <- excel_sheets(excel_path)

my_sheets


We can then read in the data based on the excel sheet.


read_excel(excel_path, 
           sheet = my_sheets[1])


read_excel(excel_path, 
           sheet = my_sheets[2])




Native .RDS files
We can read in native .RDS files with the readRDS() function.


readRDS("data/UADAggs_nat_V3_0.RDS")


.RDS files are files specific to R and are relatively small.



Arrow: .feather and .parquet
Feather and Parquet formats are designed to be faster and more streamlined than other data formats, especially for big data (large data frames). Some estimates find them to take up at least 87 percent less space and be 34 times faster to read in as compared to .csv files. For reference, even .csv files are much faster to read into R than .sas7bdat files.
Tehse files achieve this with binary storge in columnar format as opposed to a row-based format. Each column holds values for a single attribute across all rows.


Source:Medium

Here’s the code to read in these files.


read_feather("data/UADAggs_nat_V3_0.feather")
read_parquet("data/UADAggs_nat_V3_0.parquet")



Feather vs. Parquet

Both options are very fast, but Feather is faster.
Parquet is better for long-term storage and is smaller
Feather is much larger as it isn’t natively compressed (it is still 6 times smaller than its .sas7bdat equivalent). It is also likely to change its features more often, so is less stable. It is more suitable for short-term storage or intermediary datasets.







Tip



One of the only drawbacks of using these files is that because they are in binary format, the raw data version of these files cannot be easily read by humans. That’s okay, though, we can just read them in!

title: Data Import and Export
text:
Writing out data
You can similarly write out data with the following functions.

readr::write_csv(): write out .csv files
haven::write_sas(): write out .sas7bdat or .sas7bcat files
haven::write_dta(): write_out .dta files
saveRDS(): save native .RDS files
arrow::write_feather(): write out .feather files
arrow::write_parquet(): write out .parquet files


Writing out excel sheets is a little more complicated; we can set up a mini tutorial for that if folks are interested.







Note



These functions invisibly return the data frame, so you can add one of these rite_* functions at the end of a pipe if you’d like to assign a data frame while you are saving it out.

title: Data Import and Export
text:
The janitor::clean_names() function
One of the most helpful functions to use after reading in data frames is the clean_names() function from the janitor package. Variables often are read in unstandardized and are a pain to clean up.
Names resulting from this function are unique and consist of only _, numbers, and letters.
They can be piped after reading in a data frame.


read_feather("data/UADAggs_nat_V3_0.feather") |> 
  janitor::clean_names() |> 
  glimpse()
